Djokovic, the No. 1 seed, has won 10 of his 12 previous matches against Kohlschreiber, a 35-year-old German. But Kohlschreiber beat Djokovic at the Indian Wells tournament this year. If Kohlschreiber can use his varied shot selection to find Djokovic’s weaknesses early in the match, he may have a chance before Djokovic’s physical stamina can overwhelm him in the best-of-five-set format.

2019-07-01.abstract: Is it still pretending if everyone can see through it?
2019-07-01.snippet: Is it still pretending if everyone can see through it?
2019-07-01.lead_paragraph: Good therapists (does Dr. Reisman still count?) will sometimes tell you that the reason we all fall into patterns, making the same mistakes over and over, is because the pain we’ve experienced in the past drives us to recreate the situation that caused it — so we can fix it. The subconscious wants a do over. It’s why we “marry” our fathers and mothers. It’s why we become them, and then realize we’re becoming them, and then fight so hard against becoming them.
2019-07-01.headline_main: ‘Big Little Lies’ Season 2, Episode 4 Recap: Unhinged

2019-07-01.abstract: Sarah Jessica Parker’s comedy series returns for a fourth season. And the original “Veronica Mars” lands on Hulu ahead of a reboot.
2019-07-01.snippet: Sarah Jessica Parker’s comedy series returns for a fourth season. And the original “Veronica Mars” lands on Hulu ahead of a reboot.
2019-07-01.lead_paragraph: DIVORCE 10 p.m. on HBO; stream on HBO platforms. When this pitch-black comedy about the aftermath of a messy divorce debuted in 2016, critics gave it mixed reviews. Some found it too painful to enjoy, and the characters weren’t exactly a likable bunch. But its second season showed signs of improvement, mostly because we saw better sides of Frances (Sarah Jessica Parker) and Robert (Thomas Haden Church) as they moved on to different partners. In Season 3 (spoiler alert!), tensions rise as Robert’s wedding draws closer and he and Frances butt heads over their parenting styles. On the sidelines, Diane (Molly Shannon) searches for independence while her husband sits in prison, and Dallas (Talia Balsam) wrestles with a midlife crisis. Writing in The New York Times, James Poniewozik said the show isn’t “going to reinvent the breakup comedy or the HBO comedy. Its goal is more modest and midlife-appropriate: to tell one more story of two people trying to reinvent themselves.”
2019-07-01.headline_main: What’s on TV Monday: ‘Divorce’ and ‘Veronica Mars’

2019-07-01.abstract: Surfboard-packed waves, New York City views and fish tacos galore, all just a subway (or ferry) ride from Manhattan.
2019-07-01.snippet: Surfboard-packed waves, New York City views and fish tacos galore, all just a subway (or ferry) ride from Manhattan.
2019-07-01.lead_paragraph: It’s been seven years since Hurricane Sandy decimated this barrier peninsula on the southern edge of Queens, tearing the boardwalk from its moorings and scattering debris across the peninsula. But as the scars heal, the working-class neighborhood of Rockaway Beach has transformed from one of the city’s best-kept secrets to a destination beach town, where the D.F.D.’s (“down for the day” in local speak) are packed towel to towel along the expansive shoreline. The weekend A train (yes, this beach is subway-accessible) is often packed with sandy chairs and surfboards, while beach-bag-toting Manhattanites line Pier 11 in the Financial District waiting for a ferry. Indeed, the once-grungy surf town is now a cocktail of bohemia and gentrification, where the urban buzz can feel both immediate and worlds away.
2019-07-01.headline_main: 36 Hours in Rockaway Beach, Queens

2019-07-01.abstract: The chef Marcus Samuelsson has a new audio cookbook that incorporates Harlem and his restaurant Red Rooster.
2019-07-01.snippet: The chef Marcus Samuelsson has a new audio cookbook that incorporates Harlem and his restaurant Red Rooster.
2019-07-01.lead_paragraph: Take Marcus Samuelsson along with you into the kitchen or even on the subway. The chef and restaurateur, who is based in Harlem, has a new audio cookbook that incorporates the neighborhood and his flagship restaurant, Red Rooster Harlem, with stops in your home kitchen to whip up some peanut-bacon pork chops, fish in banana leaves and a Bloody Rooster cocktail. Mr. Samuelsson teams up with personalities like the writers Jelani Cobb and Dr. Jessica B. Harris to cook, with jazz and gospel in the background. The narrative covers the history of Harlem and changes in the area: “It gives people a new way to experience the community,” Mr. Samuelsson said. It comes with a digital copy of the recipes.
2019-07-01.headline_main: Sound and Flavor Made in Harlem

2019-07-01.abstract: “The Peach Truck Cookbook” has recipes for Dutch baby pancakes, cucumber gazpacho and pizza.
2019-07-01.snippet: “The Peach Truck Cookbook” has recipes for Dutch baby pancakes, cucumber gazpacho and pizza.
2019-07-01.lead_paragraph: Stephen and Jessica Rose couldn’t find juicy, fragrant fresh peaches in Nashville, where they settled as newlyweds, so they did something about it. In 2012 the couple bought bushels of peaches — Mr. Rose is from Fort Valley, Ga., and was familiar with Pearson Farm there — loaded the fruit in a 1964 Jeep Gladiator and drove around Nashville selling them on weekends in summer. They are still at it with their peach truck, and visit more than 100 cities each summer. Now the couple has a cookbook that explains peach varieties, the history of the fruit in America and how to store, ripen and peel your peaches (though they don’t mention the serrated peeler I use for the job). Adding peaches to Dutch baby pancakes, to a cucumber gazpacho, to poundcake, to a Caprese salad and to condiments for pork and salmon are first-rate suggestions. I’m not sure I need peaches on pizza or with a steak, but when you’re in the peach business there are no limits.
2019-07-01.headline_main: Just Add Peaches

2019-07-01.abstract: At Ironbound Farm in New Jersey, the owner built a giant steel grill for everyday and special meals.
2019-07-01.snippet: At Ironbound Farm in New Jersey, the owner built a giant steel grill for everyday and special meals.
2019-07-01.lead_paragraph: Before you fire up the Weber, you might want to take a trip to Ironbound Farm in Asbury, in Hunterdon County, N.J., where Charles Rosen, the owner, has completed construction of a monumental grill. Mr. Rosen calls it the “mother fire” and considers it the crowning touch at his farm, cidery, winery and tasting room. “I wanted to create a destination where chefs can cook,” he said. Mr. Rosen was inspired by Francis Mallmann, the Argentine chef known for grilling, and he worked with the metal designer Terrance Johnson and the chef Norberto Piattoni, who is from Argentina, to build the soaring, 26-foot-high sculptural steel grill. It’s now in use for burgers and sausages served in the tasting room, for whole pigs and yaks at parties open to the public and for special chef’s dinners, the next of which will be in early August with Mr. Piattoni cooking.
2019-07-01.headline_main: A Grill Big Enough for a Yak

2019-07-01.abstract: In a video, Ms. Grisham opens a path for American journalists to cover the president’s meeting with Kim Jong-un of North Korea. She has a bruise to show for it.
2019-07-01.snippet: In a video, Ms. Grisham opens a path for American journalists to cover the president’s meeting with Kim Jong-un of North Korea. She has a bruise to show for it.
2019-07-01.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Stephanie Grisham, the new White House press secretary, returned from the Demilitarized Zone with a bruise on her arm after physically pushing North Korean officials to clear a way for American journalists to cover President Trump’s meeting with the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un.
2019-07-01.headline_main: Stephanie Grisham, Trump’s New Press Secretary, Literally Pushes for Press Access

2019-07-01.abstract: Satur Farms and Rick’s Picks have you covered for your next park excursion.
2019-07-01.snippet: Satur Farms and Rick’s Picks have you covered for your next park excursion.
2019-07-01.lead_paragraph: Some picnic-worthy accouterments have just been introduced by familiar grocery store brands. After growing salad greens for over 20 years, Satur Farms, in Cutchogue, N.Y., has introduced vinaigrette-style dressings created by Eberhard Müller, an owner and a chef. Each of four varieties (spicy Asian, citrus, honey-balsamic and white truffle) comes in one-ounce single-portion packets, six to a container. They are all organic, made without preservatives and useful not just for a bowl of greens but to season seafood and grains. Also portable are single-serving packs of crisp pickle spears, the latest from Rick Field of Rick’s Picks in Brooklyn. Called “Snacking Pickles,” they come in five flavors — garlic-dill, sweet, sour, spicy Sriracha and cumin-lime-dill — in 2.2-ounce packs.
2019-07-01.headline_main: Picnic-Ready Dressings and Pickles

2019-07-01.abstract: New York has long been a haven for L.G.B.T.Q. people seeking acceptance and community. We spoke to some of those people about the ways in which their identities have changed and shaped their lives.

2019-07-01.snippet: The chocolatier and pastry chef now ships his luxurious ice cream nationwide.
2019-07-01.lead_paragraph: Jacques Torres, the chocolatier and pastry chef, has kept his ice creams as a New York thing. Now he has finally decided to share it with the rest of the country. Pints of luxurious vanilla, chocolate, strawberry, salted caramel and mocha can be ordered, starting Monday, for nationwide shipping. The ice creams are made in Mr. Torres’ s production facility in Brooklyn.

2019-07-01.snippet: Five hundred years after the artist’s death, a talk at the 92nd Street Y will discuss the culinary customs of his day.
2019-07-01.lead_paragraph: What was “brain food” for Leonardo da Vinci? You may not learn his favorite snack, but you will be treated to a discussion of the culinary customs of his day in a talk at the 92nd Street Y by Dr. Joseph Forte, the chairman of the art history department of Sarah Lawrence College, and Francine Segan, a food historian and author. It’s well-timed; this year is the 500th anniversary of da Vinci’s death.
2019-07-01.headline_main: What Was on da Vinci’s Dinner Table?

2019-07-01.lead_paragraph: Last week, the world learned the chilling news that Marshae Jones, a 28-year-old woman who was five months pregnant when shot in the stomach, has been charged with manslaughter. When a grand jury failed to indict Ebony Jemison, the woman who fired the gun, the police in Pleasant Grove, Ala., sought someone else — and landed on Ms. Jones, whom they now blame for the altercation that led to the termination of her pregnancy. To the police, if Ms. Jones had not picked a fight, her fetus would have survived.

2019-07-02.abstract: A Mexican chef takes hibiscus beyond drinks, syrups and jellies and returns it to the center of the plate.
2019-07-02.snippet: A Mexican chef takes hibiscus beyond drinks, syrups and jellies and returns it to the center of the plate.
2019-07-02.lead_paragraph: At Super King, the Armenian-owned grocery chain with a hectic parking lot near my house in Los Angeles, I buy dried hibiscus flowers in bulk from a deep self-serve bin with a perpetually sticky-handled scoop. I say “flowers,” but in the kitchen, the bright red, sour wrinkles we call hibiscus aren’t really the flowers. We cook with the thick, protective covers of the Hibiscus sabdariffa — the tart red calyxes that shield its little buds, then stay on the plant even after the flowers have bloomed and fallen.
2019-07-02.headline_main: Forget the Pork. Add Some Flower Power to Your Quesadillas.

2019-07-02.abstract: A documentary looks at a rivalry between competitive eaters. And Fritz Lang’s “Metropolis” airs alongside one of its forebears.
2019-07-02.snippet: A documentary looks at a rivalry between competitive eaters. And Fritz Lang’s “Metropolis” airs alongside one of its forebears.
2019-07-02.lead_paragraph: THE GOOD, THE BAD, THE HUNGRY 8 p.m. on ESPN. A warning to viewers: think twice before using this documentary as inspiration for your July 4 cookouts. The latest entry in ESPN’s “30 for 30” series focuses on the rivalry between the competitive eaters Takeru Kobayashi and Joey Chestnut, who was a 23-year-old engineering student from California when he defeated Kobayashi at the Nathan’s Famous Hot Dog Eating Contest in 2007. To do that, Chestnut ate 66 hot dogs in 12 minutes. “Like a particularly bloody boxing match, it was disturbing to watch,” Ken Belson wrote in The New York Times. Not all will have the stomach for the repeated footage of franks and buns disappearing into the men’s gullets like water down a drain, but those who do should enjoy the semi-serious, high-stakes tone this documentary strikes.
2019-07-02.headline_main: What’s on TV Tuesday: ‘The Good, the Bad, the Hungry’ and ‘Metropolis’

2019-07-02.abstract: Break down the characters into chunks and repeat them over and over. Write them down ASAP, even if only in the dirt.
2019-07-02.snippet: Break down the characters into chunks and repeat them over and over. Write them down ASAP, even if only in the dirt.
2019-07-02.lead_paragraph: “Memory decays very quickly,” says Caren Rotello, chairwoman of the Department of Psychological and Brain Sciences at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst. In studies about license-plate recall, people who see a plate for three or fewer seconds remember an average of around 3.5 characters (and fewer when seen reversed in a rearview mirror). After that, the more time that elapses, the more you’ll forget. “Write it down immediately,” Rotello says. “Even if you just take a stick or your finger and write in the dirt.”
2019-07-02.headline_main: How to Remember a License Plate

2019-07-02.snippet: In experiments on pig organs, scientists at Yale made a discovery that could someday challenge our understanding of what it means to die.
2019-07-02.lead_paragraph: A few years ago, a scientist named Nenad Sestan began throwing around an idea for an experiment so obviously insane, so “wild” and “totally out there,” as he put it to me recently, that at first he told almost no one about it: not his wife or kids, not his bosses in Yale’s neuroscience department, not the dean of the university’s medical school.
2019-07-02.headline_main: Scientists Are Giving Dead Brains New Life. What Could Go Wrong?

2019-07-02.lead_paragraph: I work in the public sector and have a great relationship with most of my colleagues. One of my co-workers, a caring person who works hard for the community we serve, has more than once made racially insensitive comments, using phrases like “playing the race card” and “pull yourself up by the bootstraps.” I am black, and this person is white. I’ve been honest with this person about how these comments strike me, but I get the feeling that what I’ve said has not made an impression.

The captain, as required by international rules, reported the ship’s position, course, speed and another key detail: It was riding high in the water, meaning it was probably empty.

2019-07-02.abstract: A rediscovered diary, now at the Museum of the American Revolution, sheds light on the life of Deborah Sampson, who fought in the Continental Army.
2019-07-02.snippet: A rediscovered diary, now at the Museum of the American Revolution, sheds light on the life of Deborah Sampson, who fought in the Continental Army.
2019-07-02.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Hers has always been one of the more astonishing, if little-known, tales of the American Revolution: a woman who stitched herself a uniform, posed as a man and served at least 17 months in an elite unit of the Continental Army. Wounded at least twice, Deborah Sampson carried a musket ball inside her till the day she died in 1827.
2019-07-02.headline_main: The Woman Who Sneaked Into George Washington’s Army

2019-07-02.abstract: “Perseus and Andromeda” anchors a poignant exhibition on the destruction of 18th-century frescoes in World War II.
2019-07-02.snippet: “Perseus and Andromeda” anchors a poignant exhibition on the destruction of 18th-century frescoes in World War II.
2019-07-02.lead_paragraph: The lovers are soaring through gold. In Giambattista Tiepolo’s fresco “Perseus and Andromeda,” which was painted around 1730-31 and luxuriated across the ceiling of a Milanese palazzo, a winged horse spirits away the boyish Perseus, a heroic son of Jupiter with a mop of golden hair, who has just driven his lance into a ravenous sea monster. He has rescued the chained Andromeda, and now they are flying; she’s nude but for the broken manacles still dangling from her wrists and ankles, and her skin is a blotchy peach tone, despite her heritage as princess of Aethiopia.
2019-07-02.headline_main: At the Frick, Tiepolo’s Divine Lovers, Lost to War and Resurrected

2019-07-02.abstract: The home goods retailer John Derian fills his 18th-century beach house with unlikely novelties.
2019-07-02.snippet: The home goods retailer John Derian fills his 18th-century beach house with unlikely novelties.
2019-07-02.lead_paragraph: John Derian’s second home in Provincetown, Mass. — built for a local sea captain in 1789 and purchased by Derian, the interior designer and home goods retailer, in 2007 — can resemble, at times, a particularly thoughtful cabinet of curiosities. A 19th-century flower drying rack from Denmark now displays Derian’s shirts and jackets; silvery, lightly faded midcentury wallpaper hangs in a sitting room near one of the house’s five working fireplaces, the mantel of which is clustered with shells and rocks collected from the surrounding landscape. Large, oil paintings of a dog and a cat, acquired at a flea market in Paris, add whimsy to the kitchen; a copy of Rembrandt’s portrait of his mother, purchased at a Wellfleet flea market, hangs nearby.
2019-07-02.headline_main: A Whimsical Provincetown Home, Where Everything Is a Treasure

2019-07-02.snippet: A pan-Asian food court in Elmhurst, Queens; a wine bar in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn; and more restaurant news.
2019-07-02.lead_paragraph: In Northern China, particularly in Beijing, hutongs are old, narrow alleyways. They’re lined with small houses that have courtyards, some of which house restaurants. The branch of Hutong about to open in the Bloomberg L.P. headquarters is in a courtyard, to be sure, but it has turned the far-from-humble space that housed Le Cirque into a statement of jaw-dropping Art Deco grandeur, with a soaring blue and silver dining room and white marble details. “I consider New York to be the Art Deco capital, and I wanted to pay homage to it and also to Art Deco of Shanghai,” said David Yeo, the founder of the Hong Kong-based Aqua Restaurant Group, which owns this Hutong, as well as others in London and Asia. He said his mandate for Robert Angell, the designer, was “no red lanterns, no stereotypes.” This branch contrasts with the one in London, on 33rd floor of the Shard building, which has an Imperial Palace profusion of gilt, black and red. Mr. Yeo’s Hutong restaurants specialize in Northern Chinese food, so expect impressive platters heaped with crisp soft-shell crabs, chile-fueled beef tenderloin ma la style, the inevitable Peking duck and, specifically for New York, deep-fried prawns with pickled vegetables, broad beans with Sichuan sauce, and squid “flowers” with chile dressing. In the evening, dim sum are served in the warmly lit contemporary bar and the dining room. It will also be served for lunch, which starts in a week. (Opens Monday)
2019-07-02.headline_main: Hutong, Northern Chinese in Former Le Cirque Space, Opens

2019-07-02.lead_paragraph: We horror-movie lovers are cheap dates. A creaking door and a shocking edit can be all it takes for us to yelp in surrender, as our sympathetic nervous systems kick in and we grab our seat arms or each other. Ari Aster, who made a splash last summer with his feature directing debut, “Hereditary,” understands the genre’s fundamentals. But his strength in that movie and his new one, “Midsommar,” is the setup, that part when he lays out his characters, their worlds and the menace that closes on them like a claw.

2019-07-02.lead_paragraph: Our little river cabin caught on fire from grease burning on the stove. Miles away from the nearest Alabama volunteer fire department, we tried to put out the flames with the garden hose. Hours later, amid the blackened walls and stench of burned furniture and plastic, we finally slept. The next morning, I wept as we stood in what was left of the kitchen. My darling reached up to the sooted ceiling with one finger and wrote, “Will you marry me?” I stopped crying just long enough to reach up and write, “O.K.” — Gita Maritzer Smith
2019-07-02.headline_main: Tiny Love Stories: ‘In the Summer, We Sleep Naked’

2019-07-02.abstract: How do you find independence when you’re coming of age with autism?
2019-07-02.snippet: How do you find independence when you’re coming of age with autism?
2019-07-02.lead_paragraph: In the fall of 2006, when I reached out to the Floquet-McGovern family as part of a photography project about raising children on the autism spectrum, I thought I’d spend one afternoon at their house in western Massachusetts. I spent 12 years with them instead. Over the next decade, I kept traveling from my home in Providence, R.I.,  to watch Super Bowls with them, ride around in their minivan, sleep on the floor of their hotel room, attend their school concerts, trick-or-treat with them, and sing karaoke in their basement.

2019-07-03.abstract: A docuseries about the Romanov family premieres on Netflix. And a film about one of the bloodiest incidents in British history comes to Amazon.
2019-07-03.snippet: A docuseries about the Romanov family premieres on Netflix. And a film about one of the bloodiest incidents in British history comes to Amazon.
2019-07-03.lead_paragraph: OPHELIA (2018) Stream on IFC Films. Imagine if Shakespeare’s “Hamlet” were told from Ophelia’s perspective. This film, directed by Claire McCarthy, follows Ophelia (Daisey Ridley), a Danish orphan who becomes a lady in waiting to Queen Gertrude (Naomi Watts). Soon she and a young Prince Hamlet (George MacKay) fall in love. But Ophelia’s devotion is tested as Hamlet’s desire to avenge his father’s death overtakes him. In her review in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis wrote: “‘Ophelia’ seeks to revamp the image of its title heroine as a tragic, largely passive casualty, one who is as much a victim of Shakespeare’s era as of his peerless imagination. It’s an interesting exercise and, for the most part, a passably diverting one.”
2019-07-03.headline_main: What’s on TV Wednesday: ‘The Last Czars’ and ‘Peterloo’

2019-07-03.abstract: A healthy man spends his vacation worrying. Was it worth it?
2019-07-03.snippet: A healthy man spends his vacation worrying. Was it worth it?
2019-07-03.lead_paragraph: The sound of his kids splashing in the pool and the wind off the ocean made it hard for the 44-year-old man to hear his doctor’s voice on the phone. “Your blood tests got worse, not better,” said the voice, referring to the levels of certain enzymes in the man’s liver. The doctor was concerned enough to call his patient who was half an ocean away on vacation with his family. He would need to see a liver specialist as soon as he returned from Christmas break, the doctor instructed.
2019-07-03.headline_main: Routine Testing for Life Insurance Turns Up Potential Liver Problems

2019-07-03.abstract: Ankle bracelets are promoted as a humane alternative to jail. But private companies charge defendants hundreds of dollars a month to wear the surveillance devices. If people can’t pay, they may end up behind bars.

2019-07-03.abstract: Growing up around veterans inspired me to serve my country, but life on the ground in Iraq was more stigmatizing than I anticipated.
2019-07-03.snippet: Growing up around veterans inspired me to serve my country, but life on the ground in Iraq was more stigmatizing than I anticipated.
2019-07-03.lead_paragraph: I spent 10 years in the Army, first in the Reserves and then on active duty, but much of my experience is neatly encapsulated by one incident, early in my first overseas tour during the initial invasion of Iraq in 2003, when I almost took an unauthorized shower.
2019-07-03.headline_main: While I Was on Deployment, a Learning Disability Nearly Broke Me. But I Persevered.

2019-07-03.abstract: Saudi Arabia has quietly directed tens of millions of dollars a year to American universities from M.I.T. to Northern Kentucky. What are the nation’s rulers getting out of it?
2019-07-03.snippet: Saudi Arabia has quietly directed tens of millions of dollars a year to American universities from M.I.T. to Northern Kentucky. What are the nation’s rulers getting out of it?
2019-07-03.lead_paragraph: One spring afternoon last year, protesters gathered on a sidewalk alongside a busy street in Cambridge, Mass. City buses rolled past. Car horns sounded. A few pedestrians paused briefly before continuing on their way. The location was 77 Massachusetts Avenue, in front of a limestone-and-concrete edifice that serves as the gateway into the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. The building’s lobby leads to a long hallway known as the Infinite Corridor and into the heart of one of America’s most vaunted academic institutions.
2019-07-03.headline_main: Why Is There So Much Saudi Money in American Universities?

2019-07-03.abstract: Most of us eat more when we exercise, and though it may be just a few extra bites a day, the result is weight gain.
2019-07-03.snippet: Most of us eat more when we exercise, and though it may be just a few extra bites a day, the result is weight gain.
2019-07-03.lead_paragraph: People hoping to lose weight with exercise often wind up being their own worst enemies, according to the latest, large-scale study of workouts, weight loss and their frustrating interaction. The study, which carefully tracked how much people ate and moved after starting to exercise, found that many of them failed to lose or even gained weight while exercising, because they also reflexively changed their lives in other, subtle ways. But a few people in the study did drop pounds, and their success could have lessons for the rest of us.
2019-07-03.headline_main: Why So Many of Us Don’t Lose Weight When We Exercise

2019-07-03.abstract: Dinghies are a means to salvation, not just from a shipwreck, but as an escape from the catastrophes of life — including one’s own family.
2019-07-03.snippet: Dinghies are a means to salvation, not just from a shipwreck, but as an escape from the catastrophes of life — including one’s own family.
2019-07-03.lead_paragraph: I first learned to row because I wanted to escape the people I loved. My family spent summer weekends on a semi-rotted wooden sailboat. It was basically a floating camper van we drove up and down the coast of Maine, except that we couldn’t easily leave it when we stopped for the night. If one of us wanted space or privacy, we got into the dinghy — a smaller boat we towed off the stern — and rowed to an uninhabited island to stare at rocks and reset our mood. Our boat was named Second Chance by its previous owners; we memorialized our need for the occasional sanity-restoring break from one another by naming our dinghy Last Chance.
2019-07-03.headline_main: Letter of Recommendation: Dinghy Rowing

2019-07-03.lead_paragraph: Moe Moskowitz, the co-founder of Moe’s Books in Berkeley, was known for a lot of things: his omnipresent cigars; his appalling dancing (sometimes to Cab Calloway on the store’s turntable); his political activism; and especially the way he held court at the cash register, riffing like Jackie Mason at a Friars Club podium.

2019-07-03.abstract: Julie Dash, Matty Rich, Darnell Martin, Ernest Dickerson, Leslie Harris and Theodore Witcher on a boom that went bust, and what’s different now.
2019-07-03.snippet: Julie Dash, Matty Rich, Darnell Martin, Ernest Dickerson, Leslie Harris and Theodore Witcher on a boom that went bust, and what’s different now.
2019-07-03.lead_paragraph: For the first time in a long time, things seemed to be changing in Hollywood. Black filmmakers were making inroads where their white counterparts had long been parked, bringing with them an array of perspectives and experiences seldom recognized by mainstream American production companies. The bad old days — of blackface and white saviors, of “colorblind” studio executives and all-white Oscar nominees — grew, for a while, hazy and remote, suddenly incongruous with the diverse new landscape.
2019-07-03.headline_main: ‘They Set Us Up to Fail’: Black Directors of the ’90s Speak Out

2019-07-03.abstract: Our baby had a fatal birth defect. My federal health insurance plan refused to cover the abortion.
2019-07-03.snippet: Our baby had a fatal birth defect. My federal health insurance plan refused to cover the abortion.
2019-07-03.lead_paragraph: When I was 20 weeks pregnant, I and my husband learned during a routine ultrasound that our baby had not developed a major portion of her brain and  never would. The condition, anencephaly, a type of neural tube defect that also stunts the growth of the skull, is terminal. If carried to term, our baby would be very unlikely to survive for more than a few hours.
2019-07-03.headline_main: I Shouldn’t Be Forced to Give Birth to a Baby Who Won’t Live

2019-07-03.snippet: A minimalist home in the Hudson Valley designed by the Chinese artist Ai Weiwei, an 1883 Tudor in Evanston and a medieval-style castle in Kansas City.
2019-07-03.lead_paragraph: The only private residence in the United States designed by Ai Weiwei, this home was commissioned in 2006 by Christopher Tsai, a financier and major collector of work by the Chinese artist. Mr. Ai collaborated with HHF Architects in Switzerland to develop the two-building complex: a blocky main house with a corrugated metal skin and a weathered Corten-steel guesthouse shaped like the letter Y. The property encompasses 37.5 acres in the Hudson Valley, about two hours north of New York City. Hudson, N.Y., with its high-end restaurants, design boutiques and train service, is 13 miles northwest.

2019-07-03.abstract: In his musical memory play at the Public Theater, he’s no longer being indirect about the violence that shaped, and shadowed, his life.
2019-07-03.snippet: In his musical memory play at the Public Theater, he’s no longer being indirect about the violence that shaped, and shadowed, his life.
2019-07-03.lead_paragraph: These are the facts, more or less: On Dec. 5, 1975, Ronald Egleton, of Luton, England, killed his wife, Barbara Egleton, bludgeoning her with a hammer and leaving her in the bathtub to drown. Convicted of her murder, he served 18 months in various prisons, then returned home, prompting his older son, David Egleton, to run away, first to his grandmother’s, then to London and then to America. David Egleton gave himself a new name, David Cale, and a new life as a playwright and performance artist.
2019-07-03.headline_main: David Cale Has a New Story to Tell: His Own

2019-07-03.lead_paragraph: Good morning. I was on an adventure with one of my kids. We’d eaten a lot of cheese pupusas at El Nopal in Patchogue, the hot masa slathered in salsa roja and washed down with mango purée, then driven sleepily into Blue Point and west along Middle Road to Meadow Croft, the former summer estate of John Ellis Roosevelt, now a Suffolk County Park. A storm roared in along the Great South Bay as we were touring the house and put a tree across the driveway, so we were on the grounds for a while.
2019-07-03.headline_main: A Cake for America

2019-07-03.abstract: The only way to change the future of Cuba is to keep raising our voices and march against the long-lived revolutionary system.
2019-07-03.snippet: The only way to change the future of Cuba is to keep raising our voices and march against the long-lived revolutionary system.
2019-07-03.lead_paragraph: HAVANA — For 12 years the government allowed a march through the streets in support of L.G.B.T.Q. rights. This year, the regime ordered its cancellation. Nevertheless, I and a group of friends joined others in May and peacefully walked seven blocks before a cordon of police officers violently shut down the march. The confrontation was just another example of a great dichotomy in Cuba, an island divided — and threatened — by age.
2019-07-03.headline_main: Young People Are Fleeing Cuba. But I’m Staying.

2019-07-03.abstract: A trailblazing exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum explores our fascination with the moon, from the first time Galileo trained his telescope on it to the present.
2019-07-03.snippet: A trailblazing exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum explores our fascination with the moon, from the first time Galileo trained his telescope on it to the present.
2019-07-03.lead_paragraph: Century after century, the moon adamantly refused to give up its secrets. The ancient Greeks and Romans generally considered it pristine, smooth and white, but did not have a good explanation for the dirty spots on its face that were visible to human eyes. Then, around 90 A.D., Plutarch wrote that those blemishes were the shadows of mountains and valleys and that the moon must be habitable.
2019-07-03.headline_main: The Moon Sits for Its Portrait

2019-07-03.abstract: The New York photographer Kwame Brathwaite helped ignite a global celebration of African-American style and identity.
2019-07-03.snippet: The New York photographer Kwame Brathwaite helped ignite a global celebration of African-American style and identity.
2019-07-03.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Images of black Americans’ deaths and suffering have been a permanent fixture in our cultural history, while those celebrating black personhood and pleasure have been less widely known and shown. Recent years have brought a range of efforts to balance this trend, from the scholar Deborah Willis’s book “Posing Beauty: African American Images from the 1890s to the Present” to the hashtag #BlackGirlMagic. The exhibition “Black Is Beautiful: The Photography of Kwame Brathwaite,” organized by the Aperture Foundation and accompanied by a publication of the same title, is the latest — a tribute to a man who captured the soul of a new movement celebrating African-American style and identity (and whose achievements are now inspiring the pop star Rihanna).
2019-07-03.headline_main: Uncovering the Soul of the ‘Black Is Beautiful’ Movement

2019-07-03.abstract: The N.B.A. season ended in a whirl of torn connective tissue. Sports fans see those dramatic injuries replayed just as often as the usual game highlights.
2019-07-03.snippet: The N.B.A. season ended in a whirl of torn connective tissue. Sports fans see those dramatic injuries replayed just as often as the usual game highlights.
2019-07-03.lead_paragraph: Kevin Durant’s defining quality, as arguably the world’s greatest basketball player, has always been his ease. He dominates other pros like a grown uncle bossing the mini-hoop at his nephew’s backyard birthday party. Type Durant’s name into a search bar, and you can binge for hours on mesmerizing footage of him gently devastating his peers. He blocks an opponent’s shot while wearing only one shoe. He bounds through crowds of defenders with two giant steps, then dunks almost as an afterthought. He makes impossible last-second game-winning shots as casually as the rest of us might toss our car keys into a bowl on the coffee table. Once, using the subtlest of shot fakes, Durant sent LeBron James sliding helplessly to the floor, out of bounds, and then cruised politely forward for two points. Sometimes this ease can work against him: Durant’s dominance looks anticlimactic, and his highlights hardly even scan as highlights. He’s like a superhero with too many super​powers. Of course he wins in the end.
2019-07-03.headline_main: Why Do Sports Fans Watch, and Rewatch, Injury Footage?

2019-07-03.abstract: An exhibition at the New-York Historical Society showcases photojournalism by six women on the magazine’s front lines
2019-07-03.snippet: An exhibition at the New-York Historical Society showcases photojournalism by six women on the magazine’s front lines
2019-07-03.lead_paragraph: From the depths of the Depression to the height of the Vietnam War, the photo essays in Life magazine told Americans how to see themselves. But in the 36 years that the magazine was published as a weekly, only six of its full-time photographers were women. A mix of published and unpublished shots and the contact sheets from exactly one photo essay by each of these six make up “Life: Six Women Photographers” at the New-York Historical Society’s Center for Women’s History.
2019-07-03.headline_main: The Female Gaze Behind Life Magazine

2019-07-04.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal appeals court in San Francisco on Wednesday upheld a block on President Trump’s attempt to use $2.5 billion from the Department of Defense to construct a wall along the southwestern border, impeding the delivery of one of his signature campaign promises.
2019-07-04.headline_main: Appeals Court Upholds Ruling Blocking Trump From Using Defense Funds for Border Wall

2019-07-04.abstract: German went six innings and gave up just five hits after returning from the injured list.
2019-07-04.snippet: German went six innings and gave up just five hits after returning from the injured list.
2019-07-04.lead_paragraph: By now, the Yankees know their batters are capable of posting back-to-back doubles in one inning and back-to-back home runs five innings later, just as they did in beating the Mets, 5-1, on Wednesday night at Citi Field.
2019-07-04.headline_main: Yankees Beat the Mets With a Strong Start From Domingo German

2019-07-04.abstract: Mr. Sigley, whose family raised alarms last week after losing contact with him, declined to say on Thursday why he had been detained.
2019-07-04.snippet: Mr. Sigley, whose family raised alarms last week after losing contact with him, declined to say on Thursday why he had been detained.
2019-07-04.lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — An Australian student at a North Korean university whose family lost contact with him last week was freed from detention on Thursday by the North after Swedish officials took up his plight with Kim Jong-un’s government.
2019-07-04.headline_main: Alek Sigley, Australian Student, Is Freed From Detention in North Korea

2019-07-04.abstract: Roger Federer and Serena Williams are in action, but many eyes will be on Rafael Nadal and Nick Kyrgios.
2019-07-04.snippet: Roger Federer and Serena Williams are in action, but many eyes will be on Rafael Nadal and Nick Kyrgios.
2019-07-04.lead_paragraph: Last month Nadal won his 12th title at Roland Garros, losing only two sets along the way. Although he has won just two Wimbledon titles, the third-seeded Nadal looks in fine form at majors this year, having also reached the final at the Australian Open. None of that will intimidate Kyrgios, the enigmatic player who can throw tantrums one minute and make subliminally difficult shots the next. Kyrgios has beaten Nadal three times, including in the fourth round at Wimbledon in 2014, when Nadal was the No. 1 seed. After Kyrgios defeated Nadal at the Acapulco Open in February, Nadal said he “lacks respect for the crowd, his opponent and towards himself.” Kyrgios lived up to this description in his first-round match, a five-set spectacle against Jordan Thompson, in which he alternated between joking with the crowd, admonishing himself for poor decision making, and trying to be conciliatory. Late Wednesday night, Kyrgios was even spotted by reporters at a Wimbledon Village bar. It’s hard to know which version of Kyrgios will show up Thursday, but, at the least, you can expect a match full of scorching forehands and high emotions under the watchful eye of the Centre Court crowd.
2019-07-04.headline_main: What to Watch Thursday at Wimbledon

2019-07-04.abstract: “Stranger Things” returns for a third season on Netflix. And Macy’s Fourth of July celebration broadcasts from New York.
2019-07-04.snippet: “Stranger Things” returns for a third season on Netflix. And Macy’s Fourth of July celebration broadcasts from New York.
2019-07-04.lead_paragraph: STRANGER THINGS Stream on Netflix. After a bit over a year and a half off, the 1980s are back. Or at least the ’80s as shown through the Spielbergian lens of this Netflix sci-fi horror series, which follows a group of Midwestern youths coming-of-age in a town that exists in the shadow of the supernatural. Season 2 ramped up the emotion and romance amid the chaos. Season 3 finds the friends in the summer between middle school and high school — so it’ll probably be downright terrifying. (In an interview with The New York Times, the actor Cary Elwes, who plays the town mayor this season, mentioned “Fast Times at Ridgemont High” as a primary influence for Season 3.) The neon nostalgia factor runs high.  “I always wonder if Apple iPhones and all these electronics that we use today are still going to be a thing in like 10, 20 years,” the actor Noah Schnapp, who plays one of the friends, recently told The Times. “It’s nice being on set, because it teaches you, oh, you don’t need your phone all the time. People lived like this.”
2019-07-04.headline_main: What’s on TV Thursday: ‘Stranger Things’ and Fireworks

2019-07-04.abstract: The Polish-American architect Daniel Libeskind was asked to design an exhibit at the death camp site about faith, and to engage without distracting.
2019-07-04.snippet: The Polish-American architect Daniel Libeskind was asked to design an exhibit at the death camp site about faith, and to engage without distracting.
2019-07-04.lead_paragraph: OSWIECIM, Poland — The letter to Daniel Libeskind’s father arrived shortly after the war ended. His sister, Rozia, informed him that his family was dead. She was the only one of 10 siblings to survive Auschwitz. Over three handwritten pages in Yiddish, she detailed the horrors they endured.
2019-07-04.headline_main: For Artist at Auschwitz, a Challenge: Stepping Into the Past, Not on It

2019-07-04.abstract: Anchorage could set a heat record this week, with a forecast high potentially reaching 90 degrees. The city has canceled its Fourth of July fireworks celebration.
2019-07-04.snippet: Anchorage could set a heat record this week, with a forecast high potentially reaching 90 degrees. The city has canceled its Fourth of July fireworks celebration.
2019-07-04.lead_paragraph: Updated July 5, 2019: Anchorage’s official weather station recorded a temperature of 90 degrees on Thursday afternoon, shattering the previous record high of 85 degrees.
2019-07-04.headline_main: Anchorage Had Never Reached 90 Degrees. That Changed This Week.

2019-07-04.abstract: Moving from poverty to wealth from one generation to the next is least likely in the South, but optimism there is greatest, tinged with political views.
2019-07-04.snippet: Moving from poverty to wealth from one generation to the next is least likely in the South, but optimism there is greatest, tinged with political views.
2019-07-04.lead_paragraph: HUNTSVILLE, Ala. — A widening income gap and sagging social mobility have left dents in the American dream. But the belief that anyone with enough gumption and grit can clamber to the top remains central to the nation’s self-image.
2019-07-04.headline_main: Southerners, Facing Big Odds, Believe in a Path Out of Poverty

2019-07-04.abstract: Nicholas Hytner’s production at the Bridge Theater in London finds something fresh in a work that sometimes feels as if it’s being done out of duty.
2019-07-04.snippet: Nicholas Hytner’s production at the Bridge Theater in London finds something fresh in a work that sometimes feels as if it’s being done out of duty.
2019-07-04.lead_paragraph: LONDON — This summer will see no fewer than five productions of “A Midsummer Night’s Dream” in and around London. But I intend no disrespect to the others when I bet that Nicholas Hytner’s immersive production at the Bridge Theater  is unlikely to be equaled. The play runs through Aug. 31 and will be broadcast in movie theaters around the world via NT Live on Oct. 17.
2019-07-04.headline_main: In a New ‘Midsummer Night’s Dream,’ Darkness and Wonder

2019-07-04.abstract: Some areas have seen as much as three feet of rainfall since the weekend.
2019-07-04.snippet: Some areas have seen as much as three feet of rainfall since the weekend.
2019-07-04.lead_paragraph: More than a million people were told to evacuate their homes in southern Japan this week as heavy rains caused mudslides and flooding, dumping as much as three feet of water in some areas. One person was confirmed dead, another was missing and at least four were injured in Kagoshima Prefecture, the hardest-hit area.
2019-07-04.headline_main: Photos of Heavy Rains in Japan

2019-07-04.abstract: Many of us have half-quit apps like Twitter and Instagram. It’s awful.
2019-07-04.snippet: Many of us have half-quit apps like Twitter and Instagram. It’s awful.
2019-07-04.lead_paragraph: Everyone has that one app. The one that mocks you from your home screen. The app that lures you to the folder where you’ve tried to hide it. The app you’ve signed out of and deleted — only to download again the next morning. The app you can’t quite quit.
2019-07-04.headline_main: The Horrible Place Between the Apps

2019-07-04.abstract: Pets provide comforts that seem tailor-made for the stresses of normal adolescent development.
2019-07-04.snippet: Pets provide comforts that seem tailor-made for the stresses of normal adolescent development.
2019-07-04.lead_paragraph: People of all ages become deeply connected to their pets, but in the lives of teenagers, animals often play a special role. Indeed, pets provide comforts that seem to be tailor-made for the stresses of normal adolescent development.
2019-07-04.headline_main: What Do Teenagers Need? Ask the Family Dog

2019-07-04.abstract: A young minister and his wife scour Upper Manhattan for their first New York rental. Which one did they choose?

2019-07-04.snippet: The decree now in effect also exempts visa requirements for citizens from Canada, Japan and Australia.
2019-07-04.lead_paragraph: For some travelers, visiting Brazil was made a little easier in June, when a decree signed by President Jair Bolsonaro went into effect, eliminating visa requirements for citizens from the United States, Canada, Japan and Australia.
2019-07-04.headline_main: Brazil Eases Visa Requirements for U.S. Travelers

2019-07-04.abstract: The former baseball commissioner, whose new memoir is “For the Good of the Game,” was a voracious childhood reader, “mostly about sports,” and especially “novels about the Brooklyn Dodgers.”
2019-07-04.snippet: The former baseball commissioner, whose new memoir is “For the Good of the Game,” was a voracious childhood reader, “mostly about sports,” and especially “novels about the Brooklyn Dodgers.”
2019-07-04.lead_paragraph: The former baseball commissioner, whose new memoir is “For the Good of the Game,” was a voracious childhood reader, “mostly about sports,” and especially “novels about the Brooklyn Dodgers.”

2019-07-04.abstract: Investors expect even lower growth and inflation; this isn’t the way it’s supposed to work.
2019-07-04.snippet: Investors expect even lower growth and inflation; this isn’t the way it’s supposed to work.
2019-07-04.lead_paragraph: American borrowing costs keep plunging, and that is signaling something important: Some of the basic assumptions of the most influential economic technocrats in the land are, for the time being at least, off base.
2019-07-04.headline_main: Interest Rates Just Keep Falling. Economic Orthodoxy Is Falling With Them.

2019-07-04.abstract: As long as people have smoked the plant, they’ve debated what to call it. And now marketers for the legal marijuana industry want everyone to say “cannabis.”
2019-07-04.snippet: As long as people have smoked the plant, they’ve debated what to call it. And now marketers for the legal marijuana industry want everyone to say “cannabis.”
2019-07-04.lead_paragraph: Kush. Bud. Herb.
2019-07-04.headline_main: Marijuana, Reefer, Weed: Language and the Devil’s Lettuce

2019-07-04.abstract: Nick Broomfield’s remarkable documentary explores the love between Leonard Cohen and Marianne Ihlen.
2019-07-04.snippet: Nick Broomfield’s remarkable documentary explores the love between Leonard Cohen and Marianne Ihlen.
2019-07-04.lead_paragraph: When you go to see a documentary film by Nick Broomfield, you are likely to see Nick Broomfield himself. His mode of inquiry, whether he’s examining murderers, politicians or rock stars (subjects of his previous pictures include Aileen Wuornos, Sarah Palin, Courtney Love and Kurt Cobain), always insists on exposing the inquiry itself. And like Michael Moore, Broomfield has the personality to make his onscreen presence interesting even if you’re not keen on meta-documentary.
2019-07-04.headline_main: ‘Marianne & Leonard’ Review: An Emotionally Complex Story of a Poet and His Muse

2019-07-04.abstract: The Women’s World Cup set records for television audiences worldwide, but the growth magnified challenges for reporters who started chronicling the sport before its big breakout.
2019-07-04.snippet: The Women’s World Cup set records for television audiences worldwide, but the growth magnified challenges for reporters who started chronicling the sport before its big breakout.
2019-07-04.lead_paragraph: MONTPELLIER, France — Eleven million viewers in France. More than 30 million more in Brazil tuning in to watch its long-ignored national team. A tense England-United States semifinal that became — with 11.7 million viewers — the most-watched television program in Britain this year.
2019-07-04.headline_main: World Cup Reporters Find Huge Audiences and Familiar Challenges

2019-07-04.abstract: The field of 24 candidates is too unwieldy, some Democrats say. But with big names like the Clintons and Obamas remaining silent, the party lacks anyone to sort it out.
2019-07-04.snippet: The field of 24 candidates is too unwieldy, some Democrats say. But with big names like the Clintons and Obamas remaining silent, the party lacks anyone to sort it out.
2019-07-04.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — John Deeth is the sort of Iowa activist who keeps up with every new twist in the Democratic presidential primary, but there was no way he was going to devote two evenings to watching the first round of debates last week.
2019-07-04.headline_main: Democrats Grapple With a Sprawling Primary Field, and No One to Shape It

2019-07-04.abstract: From Brooklyn Brewery bottles to the Jean Georges menu, Milton Glaser’s logos are all over the city. He’s not even thinking of retiring.
2019-07-04.snippet: From Brooklyn Brewery bottles to the Jean Georges menu, Milton Glaser’s logos are all over the city. He’s not even thinking of retiring.
2019-07-04.lead_paragraph: Lots of people say they love their hometown, but no one hearts NY quite like Milton Glaser. A native of the Allerton section of the Bronx and a graduate of the Cooper Union, Mr. Glaser, who turned 90 last week, has been creating a whimsical, optimistic, mildly trippy visual language for the city and state since 1954. The images here are among 3,600 of his designs — for consumer products, logos, restaurant interiors, book covers, magazines and more — accessible to the public in his archive at the School of Visual Arts in Manhattan, where he taught for almost 60 years until 2017.
2019-07-04.headline_main: Why This Famous Graphic Designer, at 90, Still ♥s NY

2019-07-04.abstract: To translate 50 news articles a week, NYT en Español looks for the common ground in a language spoken by 500 million people in many different ways.
2019-07-04.snippet: To translate 50 news articles a week, NYT en Español looks for the common ground in a language spoken by 500 million people in many different ways.
2019-07-04.lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
2019-07-04.headline_main: How Do You Say ‘The New York Times’ in Spanish?

2019-07-04.abstract: With Pride Month gone and scrubbed away, Wesley Morris finds a video that truly “rides the rainbow.”
2019-07-04.snippet: With Pride Month gone and scrubbed away, Wesley Morris finds a video that truly “rides the rainbow.”
2019-07-04.lead_paragraph: June was L.G.B.T.Q. Pride month. July is national pride month — at least on the Fourth. And, in New York City, the pivot from one to the other isn’t much of a pivot at all. One flag comes down and another goes up. The performance of a queer self doesn’t seem that far from the performance of an American one, especially if you catch the president’s July 4 military pageant or got a glimpse of Nike’s just-canceled sneakers with the Betsy Ross flag. But this year, in queer land, the performance of pride was conducted with a flamboyance that rivals Independence Day.
2019-07-04.headline_main: Where Do You Find Gay Pride When It’s No Longer on Sale?

2019-07-04.abstract: Pick up one of these to feel the sand beneath your toes and smell the salty, tangy ocean air.
2019-07-04.snippet: Pick up one of these to feel the sand beneath your toes and smell the salty, tangy ocean air.
2019-07-04.lead_paragraph: Sometimes what you want is not a “beach book” but a book literally set at the beach.
2019-07-04.headline_main: Can’t Make It to the Beach? These Novels Will Take You There

2019-07-04.abstract: They have pledged to help fix U.S. recycling, but for decades the companies have fought against “bottle bills,” which result in more bottles and cans being recycled but are costly for the industry.
2019-07-04.snippet: They have pledged to help fix U.S. recycling, but for decades the companies have fought against “bottle bills,” which result in more bottles and cans being recycled but are costly for the industry.
2019-07-04.lead_paragraph: Recycling is struggling in much of the United States, and companies like Coca-Cola say they are committed to fixing it.
2019-07-04.headline_main: Beverage Companies Embrace Recycling, Until It Costs Them

2019-07-04.snippet: This week’s properties include a five-bedroom in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., and a seven-bedroom in Newark, N.J.

2019-07-04.headline_main: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey

2019-07-04.abstract: Let’s all take a break from politics.
2019-07-04.snippet: Let’s all take a break from politics.
2019-07-04.lead_paragraph: PETOSKEY, Mich. — For this Fourth of July, amid picnics and parties marking Independence Day around the country, let me offer a Modest Proposal.
2019-07-04.headline_main: A Modest Proposal to Survive the 487 Days Till the Election. (But Who’s Counting?)

2019-07-04.abstract: How much joy is left to be squeezed out of watching photo-realistic animals, or new Hollywood stars, act out old movies we loved, beat for beat?
2019-07-04.snippet: How much joy is left to be squeezed out of watching photo-realistic animals, or new Hollywood stars, act out old movies we loved, beat for beat?
2019-07-04.lead_paragraph: Hollywood is, self-evidently, in the middle of a nostalgia boom. A time traveler from the mid-1990s who suddenly lands in the mezzanine of any given AMC theater this year should be forgiven for thinking his experiment failed as he watches audiences pour into theaters for “The Addams Family,” “The Lion King,” and “Men in Black” — all 2019 rejiggerings of two-decade-old movies.
2019-07-04.headline_main: Summer ’19 Brought To You By Nostalgia-Bait Movies

2019-07-04.abstract: We need to reclaim the spirit of 1776, not the certitudes of 1789.
2019-07-04.snippet: We need to reclaim the spirit of 1776, not the certitudes of 1789.
2019-07-04.lead_paragraph: I was walking through an airport terminal trying to catch a connecting flight last Saturday when I spotted a writer I had never met but whose work I admire. He greeted me with a look of fatherly concern: “Sorry about what’s happening to you on Twitter.”
2019-07-04.headline_main: Robespierre’s America

2019-07-04.abstract: ICE is not the SS or the Gestapo. But it has concerning similarities.
2019-07-04.snippet: ICE is not the SS or the Gestapo. But it has concerning similarities.
2019-07-04.lead_paragraph: On July 2, Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, after a visit to migrant detention facilities run by Customs and Border Protection in Texas, claimed that the United States is “headed toward fascism.” Much of the response that followed was expected, but little or none of it examined the statement closely or detailed to what degree the United States’ immigration policy justifies such comparisons. So how apt is this analogy between the current situation and early years of fascist regimes?
2019-07-04.headline_main: Is Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez’s ‘Fascism’ Claim Too Extreme?

2019-07-04.abstract: Those hulking relics are part of the insidious nostalgia that undergirds his “Make America Great Again” ideology.
2019-07-04.snippet: Those hulking relics are part of the insidious nostalgia that undergirds his “Make America Great Again” ideology.
2019-07-04.lead_paragraph: This article has been updated to reflect news developments.
2019-07-04.headline_main: Why Trump Likes Tanks

2019-07-04.abstract: Pope Francis’ retreat from culture-war politics has left a void that politicians have been all too eager to fill.
2019-07-04.snippet: Pope Francis’ retreat from culture-war politics has left a void that politicians have been all too eager to fill.
2019-07-04.lead_paragraph: On paper, Italy’s deputy prime minister, Matteo Salvini, is a dubious poster child for Catholicism. Mr. Salvini is divorced. He has two children by two women and is in a relationship with a third. But that hasn’t stopped him from reinventing himself as Italy’s Catholic-in-chief. “I am the last of the good Christians,” Mr. Salvini, 46, said recently, during an appearance on the popular TV show “Non è l’Arena.” “I defend our history and the existence of Catholic schools,” he said during the same appearance. “If I believe in God,” he asked rhetorically, “and if I even ask for Mary’s protection, does that bother anybody?”
2019-07-04.headline_main: How the Catholic Church Lost Italy to the Far Right

2019-07-04.abstract: It’s offensive to both politics and religion.
2019-07-04.snippet: It’s offensive to both politics and religion.
2019-07-04.lead_paragraph: Looking for a new villain to account for the polarization and sheer meanness of our current politics? Instead of blaming deep divisions over race, misogyny, immigration, income inequality and the bellicose Twitter reign of President Trump, many have seized on secularism as a scapegoat for everything that keeps politically conscious and conscientious Americans awake at night.
2019-07-04.headline_main: Stop Calling Politics Our New Religion

2019-07-04.abstract: A meeting between Russia’s president, seen as the spiritual strongman of European nationalists, and the pope, a moral voice against populism, comes amid an ideological divide in the West.
2019-07-04.snippet: A meeting between Russia’s president, seen as the spiritual strongman of European nationalists, and the pope, a moral voice against populism, comes amid an ideological divide in the West.
2019-07-04.lead_paragraph: ROME — Pope Francis is viewed by many European liberals as the greatest moral voice against the resurgence in populism and the demonization of migrants.
2019-07-04.headline_main: A Clash of Worldviews as Pope Francis and Putin Meet Again

2019-07-04.abstract: A drained-looking Jean Reno anchors this stagnant thriller from the French director Frédéric Petitjean.
2019-07-04.snippet: A drained-looking Jean Reno anchors this stagnant thriller from the French director Frédéric Petitjean.
2019-07-04.lead_paragraph: According to the publicity notes, the decision to film the French director Frédéric Petitjean’s “Cold Blood” in English was a no-brainer. Audiences might disagree.
2019-07-04.headline_main: ‘Cold Blood’ Review: The Hit Man and the Hottie

2019-07-04.abstract: New York is teeming with stray cats. Meet the people trying to do something about it.
2019-07-04.snippet: New York is teeming with stray cats. Meet the people trying to do something about it.
2019-07-04.lead_paragraph: New York’s cat lovers are probably familiar with the feeling of wanting to help out the city’s many stray felines, but Rob Fruchtman and Steven Lawrence’s modest, effective documentary “The Cat Rescuers” captures the peculiar anxiety of not being able to help all of them. The film focuses on the brave, sometimes eccentric souls who have devoted their lives to caring for the city’s cat population. As we watch their often heroic efforts, we get the nauseating sense that whatever they do will never be enough.
2019-07-04.headline_main: ‘The Cat Rescuers’ Review: A Portrait of New York’s Street Cats and Their Loyal Humans

2019-07-04.abstract: Greg Kinnear strains to convey the title character’s inner torment while making him outwardly comic.
2019-07-04.snippet: Greg Kinnear strains to convey the title character’s inner torment while making him outwardly comic.
2019-07-04.lead_paragraph: In “Phil,” Greg Kinnear acts and directs, which has left him without at least one important person to say “no.” Still, even the most exacting auteur might have labored to help him make sense of this title character. The film opens with Phil, a suicidal dentist, preparing to throw himself off a bridge, then backing off, despite the encouragement of onlookers and the thematically appropriate musical accompaniment of “(I Never Promised You a) Rose Garden” on his car radio.
2019-07-04.headline_main: ‘Phil’ Review: A Messy Story About a Suicidal Dentist

2019-07-04.abstract: This lineup of traveling shorts from America’s pre-eminent showcase for independent cinema is a decidedly mixed bag.
2019-07-04.snippet: This lineup of traveling shorts from America’s pre-eminent showcase for independent cinema is a decidedly mixed bag.
2019-07-04.lead_paragraph: At the Sundance Film Festival, shorts have to gasp to get any of the high-altitude oxygen; journalists tend to lavish their hype on features. So the festival’s annual traveling shorts program functions as a kind of counterweight. This year’s grab bag, like those of years past, is a mixed one, of award winners, nonwinners, promising shorts and meh shorts. Say this for the lineup: Of the seven movies here, no two are remotely alike.
2019-07-04.headline_main: Sundance Short Film Festival Review: Bite-Size Samplings From Park City

2019-07-04.abstract: Facing the threat of sanctions for not cracking down on militants, Pakistan is again moving against the founder of the terrorist group Lashkar-e-Taiba.
2019-07-04.snippet: Facing the threat of sanctions for not cracking down on militants, Pakistan is again moving against the founder of the terrorist group Lashkar-e-Taiba.
2019-07-04.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Under pressure from the United States and a global watchdog group, Pakistan is prosecuting the founder of the Islamist terrorist group that carried out the deadly 2008 Mumbai attacks on charges of terrorism financing, along with several of his close aides.
2019-07-04.headline_main: Pakistan Brings Terrorism Financing Charges Against Hafiz Saeed

2019-07-04.abstract: Roy Kwong, a 36-year-old legislator, has emerged as a hero for the city’s youth and a leading voice for moderation during the political crisis there.
2019-07-04.snippet: Roy Kwong, a 36-year-old legislator, has emerged as a hero for the city’s youth and a leading voice for moderation during the political crisis there.

2019-07-04.abstract: Protesters girded themselves for the possibility of more detentions and what they feared would be a citywide dragnet.
2019-07-04.snippet: Protesters girded themselves for the possibility of more detentions and what they feared would be a citywide dragnet.
2019-07-04.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Hong Kong police have announced their first arrest in connection with Monday’s assault on the territory’s legislative building, as protesters gird themselves for the possibility of more detentions and what they fear will be a citywide dragnet.
2019-07-04.headline_main: Hong Kong Police Announce First Arrest in Storming of Legislature

2019-07-04.abstract: Officials said the tanker was detained under European Union sanctions on Syria. Shipping monitors said it was also trying to skirt United States sanctions on Iran.
2019-07-04.snippet: Officials said the tanker was detained under European Union sanctions on Syria. Shipping monitors said it was also trying to skirt United States sanctions on Iran.
2019-07-04.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British marines and the port authorities in Gibraltar on Thursday detained a supertanker that was carrying crude oil from Iran to Syria, a violation of European Union sanctions against Syria. The seizure of the ship threatened to raise tensions between Iran and the West.
2019-07-04.headline_main: Gibraltar Seizes Syria-Bound Tanker Thought to Be Carrying Iranian Oil

2019-07-04.abstract: Cara Buono, who plays Mrs. Wheeler, discusses Season 3 and her part in one of the show’s most provocative pairings.
2019-07-04.snippet: Cara Buono, who plays Mrs. Wheeler, discusses Season 3 and her part in one of the show’s most provocative pairings.
2019-07-04.lead_paragraph: The pool glistens in a sultry teaser for “Stranger Things” as revelers splash and frolic beneath the summer sun. The camera briskly pans to a phalanx of leisurely ladies perched atop their chaises. In the center, Karen Wheeler, played by Cara Buono, purses her carefully crafted lips and lies in a suggestive pose. She wants to be seen.
2019-07-04.headline_main: ‘Stranger Things’: Mrs. Wheeler and Billy Pick Up Where They Left Off

2019-07-04.abstract: A reader feels slighted by her husband’s doting on another child.
2019-07-04.snippet: A reader feels slighted by her husband’s doting on another child.
2019-07-04.lead_paragraph: My husband’s brother died in his 30s, eight years ago, leaving a wife and 5-year-old son. Ever since, my husband visits his nephew, without fail, one night a week for a couple of hours. (The boy is great and doing well.) Meanwhile, we have two kids in elementary school, and my husband never gives them a two-hour stretch of undivided attention. One of our kids has autism, so it’s tricky to connect with him emotionally. But my husband doesn’t seem to try. I’m really hurt that he doesn’t spend more time with his own kids. I don’t want to say anything, though. It may put him on the defensive and make things worse. Thoughts?
2019-07-04.headline_main: Why Doesn’t He Love Our Kids Like He Loves His Nephew?

2019-07-04.snippet: At least 264 pro-government forces and 58 civilians were killed in Afghanistan during the past week.
2019-07-04.lead_paragraph: At least 264 pro-government forces and 58 civilians were killed in Afghanistan during the past week, the highest death toll of 2019. Attacks by the Taliban spiked around the country as American negotiators met with Taliban officials in the seventh round of peace talks in Doha. In Kabul, a complex Taliban attack including a car-bombing and militant assault killed at least 40 people, badly damaging a private war museum, an adjoining television station and a primary school, hurting dozens of children. In Kandahar, the Taliban launched coordinated attacks in Maruf District center, killing at least 45 security forces and eight election officials.
2019-07-04.headline_main: Afghan War Casualty Report: June 28-July 4

2019-07-04.lead_paragraph: There is some sort of hard-to-define spiritual crisis across the land, which shows up in rising depression rates, rising mental health problems. A survey that the Pew Research Center released late last year captures the mood. Pew asked people to describe the things that bring meaning to their lives. A shocking number of respondents described lives of quiet despair:
2019-07-04.headline_main: Will Gen-Z Save the World?

2019-07-05.abstract: The pain is real, but the coercion isn’t.
2019-07-05.snippet: The pain is real, but the coercion isn’t.
2019-07-05.lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s declaration that “trade wars are good, and easy to win” will surely go down in the history books as a classic utterance — but not in a good way. Instead it will go alongside Dick Cheney’s prediction, on the eve of the Iraq war, that “we will, in fact, be welcomed as liberators.” That is, it will be used to illustrate the arrogance and ignorance that so often drives crucial policy decisions.
2019-07-05.headline_main: Trump Is Losing His Trade Wars

2019-07-05.abstract: After pleas from friends and co-workers, the 81-year-old radio voice of the Yankees finally took a series off to maintain his health.
2019-07-05.snippet: After pleas from friends and co-workers, the 81-year-old radio voice of the Yankees finally took a series off to maintain his health.
2019-07-05.lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — For the first day off from his job in 30 years, the man who broadcast every pitch thrown by Mariano Rivera and every inning played by Derek Jeter planned to enjoy waking up whenever he wanted. He also had a project to tackle at home: sorting through a pile of mail that he has ignored for a while.
2019-07-05.headline_main: After 5,060 Straight Yankees Games, a Day Off for John Sterling

2019-07-05.abstract: The president began with a rare call for unity in his 45-minute speech, but mostly spent time recounting the history of the armed forces, planes punctuating his message.
2019-07-05.snippet: The president began with a rare call for unity in his 45-minute speech, but mostly spent time recounting the history of the armed forces, planes punctuating his message.
2019-07-05.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a made-for-television Independence Day production starring America’s military weaponry, President Trump on Thursday used the Lincoln Memorial as the backdrop for a tribute to the country’s armed forces and a call for unity that has been largely absent during his divisive presidency.
2019-07-05.headline_main: With Flyovers and Flags, Trump Plays M.C. for the Fourth

2019-07-05.abstract: The agreement promises an end to the standoff that has paralyzed the African country since the ouster of President Omar Hassan al-Bashir in April.
2019-07-05.snippet: The agreement promises an end to the standoff that has paralyzed the African country since the ouster of President Omar Hassan al-Bashir in April.
2019-07-05.lead_paragraph: Sudan’s military and civilian leaders announced on Friday that they had reached an agreement to share power until elections, promising an end to the standoff that has paralyzed the African country since the ouster of President Omar Hassan al-Bashir in April.
2019-07-05.headline_main: Sudan Power-Sharing Deal Reached by Military and Civilian Leaders

2019-07-05.abstract: Freddie Cheng continues his quest to “hit for the cycle.”
2019-07-05.snippet: Freddie Cheng continues his quest to “hit for the cycle.”
2019-07-05.lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — “Hitting for the cycle,” or having at least one puzzle published for each day of the week, is not the be-all, end-all of puzzle making, but it certainly shows off a constructor’s chops. It also shows an ability to understand what the needs are for puzzles on each day of the week, with the aid of the editors.
2019-07-05.headline_main: Sound Evidence

2019-07-05.abstract: General Motors’ survival may depend on transforming itself into more of a tech company at the expense of thousands of autoworkers.
2019-07-05.snippet: General Motors’ survival may depend on transforming itself into more of a tech company at the expense of thousands of autoworkers.
2019-07-05.lead_paragraph: With its focus on a future of self-driving cars and renewable fuels, General Motors is leaving some manufacturing plants like the one in Lordstown, Ohio, in its rearview. Workers who spent a lifetime at the plant — and constructed their lives around G.M. as they built the company’s cars — are losing their jobs. But this round of layoffs is different from the decades-old shifts in the auto industry. Competition from Silicon Valley, pressure from Wall Street and fundamental changes in how we get around are forcing the company to transform itself. It may be easy to say it’s not fair, but the American economy may not have room for fairness anymore.
2019-07-05.headline_main: G.M. Leaves Lordstown Behind in Hard Bet on Future

2019-07-05.abstract: Finally, I could be openly gay anywhere — except while visiting a certain relative.
2019-07-05.snippet: Finally, I could be openly gay anywhere — except while visiting a certain relative.
2019-07-05.lead_paragraph: I rang the doorbell of my grandmother’s house before remembering to pull off my wedding ring. I slipped it into my pocket and, just like that, I was someone else — an actor playing a fictional version of me.
2019-07-05.headline_main: The House Where My Husband Doesn’t Exist

2019-07-05.lead_paragraph: Chris Cline, a billionaire entrepreneur, philanthropist and political donor once called the “King of Coal,” died Thursday in a helicopter crash in the Bahamas that officials said killed seven people.

2019-07-05.abstract: Olivia Cooke and Anya Taylor-Joy play teens with dark sides in “Thoroughbreds.” And Benedikt Erlingsson’s “Woman at War” hits Hulu.
2019-07-05.snippet: Olivia Cooke and Anya Taylor-Joy play teens with dark sides in “Thoroughbreds.” And Benedikt Erlingsson’s “Woman at War” hits Hulu.
2019-07-05.lead_paragraph: THOROUGHBREDS (2018) 8:25 p.m. on HBO. “You ever think about just killing him?” That question is tossed out by Amanda (Olivia Cooke), an emotionally stunted high school student, in reference to her friend Lily’s stepfather in this debut from the writer-director Cory Finley. “How … would you?” Lily (Anya Taylor-Joy) replies, in a muted manner. Amanda and Lily are a pair of erstwhile friends brought back together by circumstance: The studious Lily is enlisted to tutor Amanda, whose troubled nature is bared at the beginning of the movie, when she kills her injured horse with a knife. This film is about their friendship, and their increasingly inability to reign in their darker sides. Though direct summation is difficult: “For all the chatter and intrigue,” Manohla Dargis wrote in her review for The New York Times, Finley “never settles on a point or theme.” But, she wrote, the director “gives the movie a professional sheen and gets fine performances from his actors.”
2019-07-05.headline_main: What’s on TV Friday: ‘Thoroughbreds’ and ‘Woman at War’

2019-07-05.abstract: Cori Gauff looks to continue her run, and Andy Murray and Serena Williams team up in mixed doubles.
2019-07-05.snippet: Cori Gauff looks to continue her run, and Andy Murray and Serena Williams team up in mixed doubles.
2019-07-05.lead_paragraph: Halep, the winner of the 2018 French Open and a former world No. 1, hasn’t had the best year. For her, that means reaching only the round of 16 at the Australian Open and the quarterfinals at the French Open. On Centre Court for the third round of Wimbledon, she will face Azarenka, another former No. 1 and the winner of two Australian Open titles. Their last meeting was at Wimbledon in 2017 in the round of 16. Halep won in two sets, but through the first two rounds this year, Azarenka has looked like the better player, losing only 10 games.
2019-07-05.headline_main: What to Watch Friday at Wimbledon

2019-07-05.abstract: A Stanford swimmer convicted of sex assault. An elite student involved in “senior salute.” A claim of “affluenza.” The infuriating yet familiar cases setting off anger at the criminal justice system.

2019-07-05.lead_paragraph: The outlines of the story were infuriating yet familiar: A young man of privilege was accused of a serious crime, arrested, prosecuted and then treated gently by a judge.
2019-07-05.headline_main: Elite Kid Justice: Are Privileged Teenagers More Likely to Get a Slap on the Wrist?

2019-07-05.abstract: With the nation’s political maps hanging in the balance, Democrats are racing to win back statehouse chambers and Republicans are rushing to defend gains from 2010.
2019-07-05.snippet: With the nation’s political maps hanging in the balance, Democrats are racing to win back statehouse chambers and Republicans are rushing to defend gains from 2010.
2019-07-05.lead_paragraph: DALLAS — Only hours after the United States Supreme Court said it could do nothing to stop partisan gerrymandering of the nation’s political maps, Eric H. Holder Jr. had a message for his fellow Democrats in downtown Dallas.
2019-07-05.headline_main: It’s Not Just the White House in 2020. The Power to Draw Maps Is Also at Stake.

2019-07-05.snippet: An Indonesian school employee who recorded her boss making lewd comments must serve six months in prison for distributing indecent material, the Supreme Court ruled.
2019-07-05.lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — A school bookkeeper in Indonesia who recorded her boss’s lewd phone call as proof she was being harassed must serve at least six months in prison for distributing obscene material, the country’s Supreme Court has ruled.
2019-07-05.headline_main: For Recording Her Boss’s Lewd Call, She, Not He, Will Go to Jail
