2019-07-25.snippet: Lawmakers had tried to send an angry message to the president over his attempts to bypass them, but they do not expect to have the votes to override the veto.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump vetoed a series of bipartisan measures on Wednesday that would have blocked the sale of billions of dollars of arms to Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates.
2019-07-25.headline_main: Trump Vetoes Bipartisan Resolutions Blocking Arms Sales to Gulf Nations

2019-07-25.abstract: Erik Agard and Andy Kravis get acrobatic with their Thursday puzzle.
2019-07-25.snippet: Erik Agard and Andy Kravis get acrobatic with their Thursday puzzle.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — I was thinking, as I did this puzzle, about various approaches to a visual grid like this one where the location of the theme is (or seems) apparent. Do you gravitate toward the rows where you can see the theme, save them for last, or just get to them as you proceed in an established order? I tend to leave them for last, the way I often eat around something I really like on a plate so I can especially enjoy my last few bites of a meal. Today, I almost couldn’t help it, because I was at least 75 percent through the fill before I figured out the fun and kinetic trick.
2019-07-25.headline_main: Up to It

2019-07-25.abstract: The coming-of-age movie “My Girl” airs on Showtime 2. And Samuel L. Jackson stars in “Coach Carter” on VH1.
2019-07-25.snippet: The coming-of-age movie “My Girl” airs on Showtime 2. And Samuel L. Jackson stars in “Coach Carter” on VH1.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: MY GIRL (1991) 8 p.m. on Showtime 2. A young Anna Chlumsky and Macaulay Culkin play best friends in this coming-of-age comedy-drama that takes place over a summer. For Vada (Chlumsky), the summer is jam-packed with many of the markers of a girl growing up and coming into her own: puberty, developing crushes and adjusting to her father’s dating a new woman. Though death is a consistent theme in Vada’s life — her father is a mortician and her mother has died — she will be devastated by an unexpected loss. In an otherwise negative review for The New York Times, Janet Maslin praised the leads, calling Chlumsky a “poised, lovely young actress.” Culkin, she added, is “a remarkably funny Everykid.”
2019-07-25.headline_main: What’s on TV Thursday: ‘My Girl’ and ‘Coach Carter’

2019-07-25.abstract: The political chaos won’t be resolved with his departure, but it is a start.
2019-07-25.snippet: The political chaos won’t be resolved with his departure, but it is a start.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico — I heard that Ricardo Rosselló, the island’s governor, was going to resign around noon on Wednesday. I made my way to La Fortaleza, the governor’s mansion, around 10 a.m. in anticipation. As the day wore into night anticipation turned to frustration. The governor had not shown his face, which enraged people even more. But the crowd refused to budge.
2019-07-25.headline_main: In Puerto Rico, Rosselló Finally Hears the People

2019-07-25.abstract: In the streets of San Juan, there was celebration after Gov. Ricardo A. Rosselló of Puerto Rico announced he would resign.
2019-07-25.snippet: In the streets of San Juan, there was celebration after Gov. Ricardo A. Rosselló of Puerto Rico announced he would resign.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN, P.R. — All day, the drums and the chants had blared through the streets outside La Fortaleza, the governor’s residence in San Juan, the Puerto Rican capital.
2019-07-25.headline_main: ‘We Just Changed History’: Cheers and Tears in San Juan

2019-07-25.snippet: The special counsel mostly stuck to his report during his congressional appearances, but he also agreed that the president was untruthful to investigators.

2019-07-25.abstract: The institution hopes to become “the epicenter of scholarship” on this artist.
2019-07-25.snippet: The institution hopes to become “the epicenter of scholarship” on this artist.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: In a peculiar twist of history, the Baltimore Museum of Art is home to what is widely believed to be the world’s largest and most comprehensive collection of work by Henri Matisse. That institution now hopes to become “the epicenter of scholarship” about the French artist, with the establishment of a center for the exhibition and study of his work that is slated to open in 2021, said Christopher Bedford, the museum’s director.
2019-07-25.headline_main: Baltimore Museum to Establish a Matisse Center in 2021

2019-07-25.abstract: “If you did a shot any time Mueller said, ‘I can’t answer that,’ you were blacked out by 10 a.m.,” Jimmy Fallon joked.

If you’re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.

2019-07-25.snippet: Hours after the rapper was formally charged with assault, the president called for him to be freed and criticized the Swedish prime minister.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: In an unusual flexing of diplomatic muscle, President Trump lashed out on Thursday at the prime minister of Sweden over what he said was the unfair treatment of the rapper ASAP Rocky, who was charged with assault earlier in the day after nearly three weeks in Swedish custody.

2019-07-25.abstract: The hoverboard creator fell into the water midway through the crossing when he tried to land on a platform to refuel.
2019-07-25.snippet: The hoverboard creator fell into the water midway through the crossing when he tried to land on a platform to refuel.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Last week, the world learned that Franky Zapata could fly, thanks to a dazzling Bastille Day performance on his hoverboard in Paris. On Thursday, as he tried to cross the English Channel, the world learned that he can also swim.
2019-07-25.headline_main: Franky Zapata’s ‘Flyboard’ English Channel Flight Failed. He Vowed to Try Again.

2019-07-25.abstract: The border between the U.S. and Mexico has long been marked by barriers. But they weren’t always about deterring immigration. Here’s how the modern border came to be, starting with the year 1848.
2019-07-25.snippet: The border between the U.S. and Mexico has long been marked by barriers. But they weren’t always about deterring immigration. Here’s how the modern border came to be, starting with the year 1848.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: The border between the U.S. and Mexico has long been marked by barriers. But they weren’t always about deterring immigration. Here’s how the modern border came to be, starting with the year 1848.
2019-07-25.headline_main: When Entering the U.S. Was as Easy as Crossing a Street

2019-07-25.abstract: The border between the United States and Mexico has long been separated by barriers. But these barriers weren’t always about deterring immigration. Here’s how the modern border came to be — starting with the year 1848.
2019-07-25.snippet: The border between the United States and Mexico has long been separated by barriers. But these barriers weren’t always about deterring immigration. Here’s how the modern border came to be — starting with the year 1848.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: The border between the United States and Mexico has long been separated by barriers. But these barriers weren’t always about deterring immigration. So we decided to take a look at how the modern border came to be — starting in the year 1848.
2019-07-25.headline_main: Long Before Border Walls, Entering the U.S. From Mexico Was as Easy as Crossing a Street

2019-07-25.abstract: Laboring to survive in the present, we simultaneously imagine our future demise.
2019-07-25.snippet: Laboring to survive in the present, we simultaneously imagine our future demise.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: Since my cancer diagnosis, I have lived intimately with thoughts of death. Cancer patients of all ages and stages, as well as people with other ruinous conditions, often experience “a double frame of mind,” as the polemicist Christopher Hitchens once put it. Laboring to survive in the present, we simultaneously imagine our future demise. Of course, feelings and beliefs about mortality range widely. But a number of thinkers have set out to help those who suspect that introspection about this state of mind may be the most important work we can undertake.
2019-07-25.headline_main: Living Intimately With Thoughts of Death

2019-07-25.abstract: Long hours, disrupted sleep and constant stress can take a biological toll on newly minted doctors. Down to the level of their genes.
2019-07-25.snippet: Long hours, disrupted sleep and constant stress can take a biological toll on newly minted doctors. Down to the level of their genes.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: I noticed my first gray hair during my medical residency. It sneaked up on me at the end of a long, frenzied shift — one of those nights when Murphy’s Law seems stronger than the law of gravity. Two of my patients did slip and fall, though, so Newton made a strong showing too.
2019-07-25.headline_main: How Job Stress Can Age Us

2019-07-25.abstract: Skateboarders have long glorified confrontations with security workers. This one led not only to a life-altering injury, but also to soul-searching in a sport about to have its Olympic debut.
2019-07-25.snippet: Skateboarders have long glorified confrontations with security workers. This one led not only to a life-altering injury, but also to soul-searching in a sport about to have its Olympic debut.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: Skateboarders have long glorified confrontations with security workers. This one led not only to a life-altering injury, but also to soul-searching in a sport about to have its Olympic debut.
2019-07-25.headline_main: A Security Worker Confronted the Skateboarders. He Ended Up With Brain Damage.

2019-07-25.abstract: When her trip to work ballooned to two hours, a Williamsburg renter decided to upgrade. Which apartment did she choose?
2019-07-25.snippet: When her trip to work ballooned to two hours, a Williamsburg renter decided to upgrade. Which apartment did she choose?
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: When her trip to work ballooned to two hours, a Williamsburg renter decided to upgrade. Which apartment did she choose?
2019-07-25.headline_main: You Make the Call: Solving the Dreaded New Jersey Commute

2019-07-25.abstract: There’s new evidence that viewing habits can affect your thinking, political preferences, even cognitive ability.
2019-07-25.snippet: There’s new evidence that viewing habits can affect your thinking, political preferences, even cognitive ability.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: Other than sleeping and working, Americans are more likely to watch television than engage in any other activity.
2019-07-25.headline_main: You Are What You Watch? The Social Effects of TV

2019-07-25.abstract: A tender, devastatingly succinct poem that positions us directly in the cross hairs of a generation-spanning despair.
2019-07-25.snippet: A tender, devastatingly succinct poem that positions us directly in the cross hairs of a generation-spanning despair.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: The perseverance required when dealing with advanced age and terminal illness can have ravaging psychological consequences on the modern family. In this tender, devastatingly succinct poem, Andrea Hollander positions us directly in the cross hairs of a generation-spanning despair: the helpless sorrow of a grown daughter watching her mother die, the unfathomable anguish of parents who never expected to outlive their offspring. In the face of such suffering, how can anyone manage to overcome other than to — as Ovid wrote — “bear and endure”? I would say: through poems like this one. Selected by Rita Dove
2019-07-25.headline_main: Poem: 636 Lyons Avenue, Apartment 1A

2019-07-25.abstract: In a survey, only about one in three American men who were at high risk for H.I.V. infection took Truvada to prevent transmission.
2019-07-25.snippet: In a survey, only about one in three American men who were at high risk for H.I.V. infection took Truvada to prevent transmission.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: Among men who are at high risk for H.I.V. infection, only about one in three is taking a drug to prevent transmission of the virus, according to a survey from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The drug, Truvada, is taken daily as part of a preventive strategy called pre-exposure prophylaxis, or PrEP.
2019-07-25.headline_main: Most High-Risk Men Don’t Take PrEP to Prevent H.I.V.

2019-07-25.abstract: Should the dogs be involved in a dispute about disgusting mouth noises?
2019-07-25.snippet: Should the dogs be involved in a dispute about disgusting mouth noises?
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: Kyle writes: My wife suffers from misophonia, and the sound of dental flossing is a trigger. I floss behind a closed door two rooms away, but she sometimes walks into the adjacent room and complains to our dogs about the noise. I don’t think she should be allowed to bad-mouth me when I’m going out of my way to be nice.
2019-07-25.headline_main: Judge John Hodgman on the Sound of Flossing

2019-07-25.abstract: California’s Napa Valley is trying hard these days to attract families, aiming to entertain visitors of all ages with hiking, biking, camps and more. Even some vineyards are getting into the game.
2019-07-25.snippet: California’s Napa Valley is trying hard these days to attract families, aiming to entertain visitors of all ages with hiking, biking, camps and more. Even some vineyards are getting into the game.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: Historically, vineyard visits rank high on the eye-roll list for children. But California’s Napa Valley is trying hard these days to attract families, aiming to entertain visitors of all ages with hiking, biking, camps and non-snooty farm-to-table experiences. Even some vineyards are getting into the game, offering lawn games and grape juice tastings.
2019-07-25.headline_main: Napa With the Family (Great Wine, Minimal Whine)

2019-07-25.abstract: “Important as it is, the language in which you write is secondary,” says Javier Marías, whose new novel is “Berta Isla.” “I myself feel much closer to many foreign authors than to many of my compatriots.”
2019-07-25.snippet: “Important as it is, the language in which you write is secondary,” says Javier Marías, whose new novel is “Berta Isla.” “I myself feel much closer to many foreign authors than to many of my compatriots.”
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: “Important as it is, the language in which you write is secondary,” says Javier Marías, whose new novel is “Berta Isla.” “I myself feel much closer to many foreign authors than to many of my compatriots.”
2019-07-25.headline_main: The Spanish Author Who Doesn’t Believe in Spanish Literature

2019-07-25.snippet: And should Democrats be fighting about busing?
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:
2019-07-25.headline_main: Why Isn’t Trump Trying to Win the Center?

2019-07-25.abstract: The Swedish company Teenage Engineering has won over kids — and professionals — with a revolutionary idea for a synthesizer: Make it simple.
2019-07-25.snippet: The Swedish company Teenage Engineering has won over kids — and professionals — with a revolutionary idea for a synthesizer: Make it simple.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: Derrick Estrada, an electronic musician who performs under the stage name Baseck, had just showered and was nursing a cup of yerba mate in the back room of the Los Angeles home that a musician friend dubbed the “synth flophouse.” It was 10 a.m. on a recent Thursday; very early, he explained, for a house full of musicians.
2019-07-25.headline_main: The $60 Gadget That’s Changing Electronic Music

2019-07-25.abstract: The nation’s ideals are under attack, and it is up to all of us to defend them.
2019-07-25.snippet: The nation’s ideals are under attack, and it is up to all of us to defend them.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: Throughout history, demagogues have used state power to target minority communities and political enemies, often culminating in state violence. Today, we face that threat in our own country, where the president of the United States is using the influence of our highest office to mount racist attacks on communities across the land. In recent weeks, he has lashed out unprompted against four freshman Democrats in the House of Representatives: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez of New York, Ayanna Pressley of Massachusetts, Rashida Tlaib of Michigan, and me, from Minnesota.
2019-07-25.headline_main: Ilhan Omar: It Is Not Enough to Condemn Trump’s Racism

2019-07-25.abstract: The social network’s new ad library is so flawed, researchers say, that it is effectively useless as a way to track political messaging.
2019-07-25.snippet: The social network’s new ad library is so flawed, researchers say, that it is effectively useless as a way to track political messaging.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: Faced with a rising backlash over the spread of disinformation in the aftermath of the 2016 elections, Facebook last year came up with a seemingly straightforward solution: It created an online library of all the advertisements on the social network.
2019-07-25.headline_main: Ad Tool Facebook Built to Fight Disinformation Doesn’t Work as Advertised

2019-07-25.abstract: The #MeToo movement is starting to shift attitudes within courts, prosecutors’ offices and, crucially, among victims.
2019-07-25.snippet: The #MeToo movement is starting to shift attitudes within courts, prosecutors’ offices and, crucially, among victims.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: [What you need to know to start the day: Get New York Today in your inbox.]
2019-07-25.headline_main: Jeffrey Epstein, R. Kelly and a Change in How Prosecutors Look at Sexual Assault

2019-07-25.abstract: In a crumbling industrial area, a mayor turned his town into a vibrant laboratory of pragmatic green policies. After his election to the European Parliament, can they be expanded?
2019-07-25.snippet: In a crumbling industrial area, a mayor turned his town into a vibrant laboratory of pragmatic green policies. After his election to the European Parliament, can they be expanded?
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: GRANDE-SYNTHE, France — Colorful condominiums with low-energy fixtures have replaced dreary old buildings. Community gardens have sprouted at the foot of public housing projects. And a flashy new fleet of buses runs on natural gas — the fare free.
2019-07-25.headline_main: A French Town’s Green Policies Aim to Win Over the Working Class

2019-07-25.abstract: What’s milk now? Vegan food companies are fed up with an onslaught of pro-meat, pro-dairy laws.
2019-07-25.snippet: What’s milk now? Vegan food companies are fed up with an onslaught of pro-meat, pro-dairy laws.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: In case you haven’t heard, they’re making meat out of plants. Burgers out of soy and coconut. Fried chicken out of jackfruit. Steaks out of “cooked wheat gluten.”
2019-07-25.headline_main: The Fake Meat War

2019-07-25.abstract: On the shores of Lake Ontario, this magical Canadian town is filled with flowers, theater, wine and plenty of opportunities for outdoor adventure.
2019-07-25.snippet: On the shores of Lake Ontario, this magical Canadian town is filled with flowers, theater, wine and plenty of opportunities for outdoor adventure.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: After watching a performance of the Shaw Festival’s “Brigadoon,” the streets of this magical town on Lake Ontario might seem like a real-life version of the Scottish village depicted in the Lerner and Loewe musical. On a recent evening, the place felt frozen in time, with horse-drawn carriages rolling down a main street lined with Victorian buildings and flower beds. But the Irish playwright and political activist Bernard Shaw, the 1925 winner of the Nobel Prize for Literature, would be proud of the modern discussions and debates that his dramas, comedies and historical plays still generate over wine from the local vineyards. Only 45 minutes from Buffalo, Niagara-on-the-Lake is also a mere 20 minutes from the Canadian side of Niagara Falls, and beyond its rich theatrical offerings, the town is filled with enough diversions — whether culinary, cultural or outdoorsy — to easily fill a weekend.
2019-07-25.headline_main: 36 Hours in Niagara-on-the-Lake

2019-07-25.abstract: The Red Sea port city of Aqaba is promoting the environmental and tourism benefits of the new underwater museum.
2019-07-25.snippet: The Red Sea port city of Aqaba is promoting the environmental and tourism benefits of the new underwater museum.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: A popular Jordanian coastal resort on the Red Sea has found a new use for out-of-service tanks, armored troop carriers and even a helicopter: as building blocks of an artificial reef and an underwater museum.
2019-07-25.headline_main: Jordan Creates Artificial Reef From Decommissioned Military Vehicles

2019-07-25.abstract: Ricardo Rosselló had a close circle of associates who shared advice and friendship. But critics said the Puerto Rico governor became too isolated from others.
2019-07-25.snippet: Ricardo Rosselló had a close circle of associates who shared advice and friendship. But critics said the Puerto Rico governor became too isolated from others.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN, P.R. — The people of Puerto Rico knew him first as Ricky, the handsome boy who moved into the governor’s residence when he was just 13. His father was the governor, and Ricardo A. Rosselló grew up as a child of privilege in historic La Fortaleza, a palatial 16th-century mansion with heavy drapes and thick wooden doors just steps from San Juan Bay.
2019-07-25.headline_main: Puerto Rico Governor Misread Anger Brewing Against Him

2019-07-25.abstract: Birchbark Books & Native Arts, owned by the novelist Louise Erdrich, provides indigenous-language guides, literature and crafts — and the latest best sellers.
2019-07-25.snippet: Birchbark Books & Native Arts, owned by the novelist Louise Erdrich, provides indigenous-language guides, literature and crafts — and the latest best sellers.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Look up when you enter Birchbark Books & Native Arts and you’ll spot a handcrafted canoe hanging above the table of current and favorite books.
2019-07-25.headline_main: Where to Find Native American Culture and a Good Read

2019-07-25.abstract: A patchwork of attempts to roll back mass incarceration and harsh sentences for crack cocaine resulted in a reunion after 13 years.
2019-07-25.snippet: A patchwork of attempts to roll back mass incarceration and harsh sentences for crack cocaine resulted in a reunion after 13 years.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: Lionel and Keith Henderson did everything together.
2019-07-25.headline_main: 2 Brothers, Same Crime: Why One Got Out First

2019-07-25.abstract: The streaming era is thought to be a golden age for women. But for Kate Micucci and many of her peers, the reality is much more complicated.
2019-07-25.snippet: The streaming era is thought to be a golden age for women. But for Kate Micucci and many of her peers, the reality is much more complicated.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: One morning last fall in Los Angeles, the comic and actress Kate Micucci sat chewing over a pitch for a television series with her writing partner, Felicia Day. How conventional would the gender roles have to be, they wondered, before a studio would bite?
2019-07-25.headline_main: Is Peak TV Really a Bonanza for Female Comics? That’s a Laugh

2019-07-25.abstract: An interactive list from the Styles desk tests a new feature and aims to distill our seasonal outrage.
2019-07-25.snippet: An interactive list from the Styles desk tests a new feature and aims to distill our seasonal outrage.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
2019-07-25.headline_main: What’s Behind All Those Hot Takes

2019-07-25.abstract: The musical based on the grandiose Meat Loaf album shines a light on its songwriter, Jim Steinman, and the many twists and turns it took to get both projects made.
2019-07-25.snippet: The musical based on the grandiose Meat Loaf album shines a light on its songwriter, Jim Steinman, and the many twists and turns it took to get both projects made.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: In the four decades since it was released, bearing the cover image of a motorcyclist blasting out of a graveyard on his bike, the Meat Loaf album “Bat Out Of Hell” has been described in many ways. Bombastic. Extravagant. Over-the-top.
2019-07-25.headline_main: Bursting Onto the Stage Like a ‘Bat Out of Hell’

2019-07-25.abstract: The soccer star will address social justice in two upcoming books.
2019-07-25.snippet: The soccer star will address social justice in two upcoming books.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: During a speech earlier this month celebrating her team’s World Cup victory, Megan Rapinoe ended with a plea to fans. “We have to be better,” she said, urging all of them to consider how they could effect change in their communities. “It’s our responsibility to make this world a better place.”
2019-07-25.headline_main: Megan Rapinoe Scores Again, but This Time It’s a Book Deal

2019-07-25.abstract: The People’s Liberation Army has kept a low profile in the city since China resumed control. But the recent protests have some fearing it could emerge from the barracks.
2019-07-25.snippet: The People’s Liberation Army has kept a low profile in the city since China resumed control. But the recent protests have some fearing it could emerge from the barracks.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — When Hong Kong, a former British colony, returned to Chinese control in 1997, one of the biggest worries was how the Chinese military would behave.
2019-07-25.headline_main: What Is the Chinese Military Doing in Hong Kong?

2019-07-25.headline_main: Mueller Testimony, Ricardo Rosselló, ASAP Rocky: Your Thursday Briefing

2019-07-25.abstract: A London production of “The Night of the Iguana” starring Clive Owen asks for the audience’s patience, and rewards it.
2019-07-25.snippet: A London production of “The Night of the Iguana” starring Clive Owen asks for the audience’s patience, and rewards it.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: LONDON — A dark night of the soul is gradually and movingly illuminated in “The Night of the Iguana,” the infrequently seen Tennessee Williams play that in fact anatomizes three souls in free fall. Widely thought to be the last great contribution from a writer who went into theatrical decline, the play is receiving a welcome revival at the Noël Coward Theater through Sept. 28.
2019-07-25.headline_main: A Quiet Take on Tennessee Williams

2019-07-25.abstract: By “democratizing finance,” the left is pushing reforms that will allow workers to get their fair share of wealth.
2019-07-25.snippet: By “democratizing finance,” the left is pushing reforms that will allow workers to get their fair share of wealth.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: Global finance has become a popular target from both the left and, more recently, the right, particularly the nationalist right. As Senator Josh Hawley, Republican of Missouri, said at the recent National Conservatism Conference, what he called the “the cosmopolitan economy” has encouraged multinational corporations to move jobs and profits overseas and then “rewarded these same corporations” for “investing their profits not in American workers, not in American development, but in financial instruments that benefit the cosmopolitan elite.”
2019-07-25.headline_main: Everyone Claims They’re Worried About Global Finance. But Only One Side Has a Plan.

2019-07-25.abstract: Britain’s new prime minister has proved he can win people over. He’ll need to now.
2019-07-25.snippet: Britain’s new prime minister has proved he can win people over. He’ll need to now.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: Boris Johnson has been Britain’s prime minister for not quite a day, and the reviews are in. He’s a disaster! A fraud! A Trumpy toff and shameless showman whose ego is inversely correlated to his merit and whose tenure of office won’t just be bad for the United Kingdom, but very possibly the death of it.
2019-07-25.headline_main: Why I’m Rooting for Boris Johnson

2019-07-25.abstract: Lawmakers came prepared for a political showdown. For the most part, the former special counsel resisted.
2019-07-25.snippet: Lawmakers came prepared for a political showdown. For the most part, the former special counsel resisted.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher
2019-07-25.headline_main: Robert Mueller’s Testimony

2019-07-25.abstract: Days after eight artists left the Whitney Biennial, the vice chairman stepped down amid criticism of how his company’s law enforcement supplies are used.
2019-07-25.snippet: Days after eight artists left the Whitney Biennial, the vice chairman stepped down amid criticism of how his company’s law enforcement supplies are used.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: Warren B. Kanders, a vice chairman of the Whitney Museum of American Art, stepped down on Thursday after months of protests over his company’s sale of tear gas, culminating in the withdrawal of eight artists last week from the prestigious Whitney Biennial exhibition.
2019-07-25.headline_main: Warren Kanders Quits Whitney Board After Tear Gas Protests

2019-07-25.abstract: After nearly two decades, 286,000 miles and countless skipped trips to the gas station, a 2000 Honda Insight in New England is ready to move on.
2019-07-25.snippet: After nearly two decades, 286,000 miles and countless skipped trips to the gas station, a 2000 Honda Insight in New England is ready to move on.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: GROVETON, N.H. — When Honda introduced the first hybrid vehicle in America, the 2000 Insight, there was technological wonder, but few would call it pretty.
2019-07-25.headline_main: The Little Hybrid That Could, and Still Can

2019-07-25.abstract: Environmentalism, in other words, is a black issue.
2019-07-25.snippet: Environmentalism, in other words, is a black issue.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: Before the first Democratic debate, I watched one of my favorite shows, MSNBC’s AM Joy, excited to see not one, but three people of color tapped to talk about climate change and how candidates were discussing it along the campaign trail. My heart dropped when Tiffany Cross, a guest commentator on the show, stated that while climate change disproportionately impacts communities of color, it’s an issue only in very “niche groups” of those communities. She wasn’t claiming that the issue wasn’t important, but that your average black person didn’t see it as an everyday thing.
2019-07-25.headline_main: Black Women Are Leaders in the Climate Movement

2019-07-25.abstract: Facebook’s huge fine, new antitrust inquiries and calls for more regulation show that government oversight is now a fact of life for Silicon Valley.
2019-07-25.snippet: Facebook’s huge fine, new antitrust inquiries and calls for more regulation show that government oversight is now a fact of life for Silicon Valley.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: Good Thursday morning. Overnight: Jeffrey Epstein was reportedly put on suicide watch yesterday after he found in his New York jail cell yesterday with injuries to his neck. (Was this email forwarded to you? Sign up here.)
2019-07-25.headline_main: DealBook Briefing: The Game Has Changed for Big Tech

2019-07-25.abstract: In office at his death, he came out of retirement to lead his country after an Arab Spring uprising ousted a dictator, then won a free election.
2019-07-25.snippet: In office at his death, he came out of retirement to lead his country after an Arab Spring uprising ousted a dictator, then won a free election.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: President Béji Caïd Essebsi, Tunisia’s first popularly elected head of state, who steered the country through a democratic transition after an uprising that set in motion the Arab Spring of 2011, died Thursday morning in Tunis. He was 92.
2019-07-25.headline_main: Béji Caïd Essebsi, President Who Guided Tunisia to Democracy, Dies at 92

2019-07-25.abstract: An intense Jamie Bell plays a tormented white supremacist in this blistering study of rage and redemption.
2019-07-25.snippet: An intense Jamie Bell plays a tormented white supremacist in this blistering study of rage and redemption.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: The British actor Jamie Bell has soft eyes and a bashful demeanor, both of which served him well as Bernie Taupin in the recent Elton John biopic, “Rocketman.” These traits must be virtually erased, however, to play the real-life former white supremacist Bryon Widner in “Skin,” a blistering story of rage and redemption that never fully illuminates the journey from one to the other.
2019-07-25.headline_main: ‘Skin’ Review: Divide and Prejudice

2019-07-25.abstract: Presenting the longtime “60 Minutes” correspondent with relatively little mediation is a natural way to his story, even as it creates a limitation.
2019-07-25.snippet: Presenting the longtime “60 Minutes” correspondent with relatively little mediation is a natural way to his story, even as it creates a limitation.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: In TV terms, the biographical film “Mike Wallace Is Here” is effectively a feature-length recap. Using only archival footage, the director Avi Belkin distills more than five decades of the longtime “60 Minutes” correspondent’s career on camera to an hour and a half. Presenting Wallace with relatively little mediation is a natural way to tell this story, even as it creates a limitation. Documentary as autobiography, the movie shows a man who is always cultivating his appearance for an audience.
2019-07-25.headline_main: ‘Mike Wallace Is Here’ Review: A Ticktock of a Newsman’s Life

2019-07-25.abstract: It’s hard to stand still when you have troublesome co-workers, a mentally ill sister and the need for exercise.
2019-07-25.snippet: It’s hard to stand still when you have troublesome co-workers, a mentally ill sister and the need for exercise.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: There are some things worse than hacking one’s way through a gig economy, particularly if you’re a woman. Take the case of Lola Wegenstein, who’s trying to find stability in multinational corporate hell. Beautifully played by Valerie Pachner in this searing film written and directed by Marie Kreutzer, Lola is attractive, intelligent, and health conscious — the opening scene shows her on a morning run. She’s also a walking ball of anxiety in her professional role at a high-powered consulting firm that trims the fat from troubled companies.
2019-07-25.headline_main: ‘The Ground Beneath My Feet’ Review: A Woman on the Run

2019-07-25.abstract: This film, set almost entirely in Afghanistan, features striking landscapes that are rarely seen onscreen.
2019-07-25.snippet: This film, set almost entirely in Afghanistan, features striking landscapes that are rarely seen onscreen.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: The real Kabul and Kandahar are almost never seen in contemporary movies, particularly those produced in the West. So the sense of going somewhere you’ve never been is palpable from almost the very beginning of “Jirga,” a fictional film shot almost entirely in and around these cities in Afghanistan.
2019-07-25.headline_main: ‘Jirga’ Review: A Soldier Returns to the Scene of His War Crime

2019-07-25.abstract: A young woman records the city around her and the violence the Syrian government and its allies loosed on civilians who rose against them.
2019-07-25.snippet: A young woman records the city around her and the violence the Syrian government and its allies loosed on civilians who rose against them.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: The gripping documentary, “For Sama,” spares a moment for levity when Waad al-Kateab films her husband, Hamza al-Kateab, as he tells a joke common in their home city of Aleppo, Syria: If you want to be safe from the government’s attacks, head to the front lines. Hospitals, like the one Hamza runs, are no guarantee of sanctuary — in fact, places that promise respite are the most frequent targets of the government’s bombs.
2019-07-25.headline_main: ‘For Sama’ Review: Out of Besieged Aleppo, a Documentary

2019-07-25.abstract: With his combination of menace and anguish, he created an unforgettable character that made the movie the classic it remains today.

2019-07-25.abstract: The Design Triennial envisions the possibilities for algae, yeast and other nonpolluting materials. Will they help save the planet?
2019-07-25.snippet: The Design Triennial envisions the possibilities for algae, yeast and other nonpolluting materials. Will they help save the planet?
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: Plastics transformed the material world after World War II. Today, they pollute our oceans. A better future will be made with … algae. Or bacteria. That’s the dominant theme of a sweeping exhibition, “Nature: Cooper Hewitt Design Triennial.” On display here at the Smithsonian’s temple to the culture of design, on upper Fifth Avenue, are objects you might once have expected only at a science museum: Proteins found in silkworms are repurposed as surgical screws and optical lenses. Electronically active bacteria power a light fixture.
2019-07-25.headline_main: Glimpsing Our Post-Consumption Future at the Cooper Hewitt

2019-07-25.abstract: When two ecologists hiking in New Zealand discovered this stump, they had to figure out how it could still be alive.
2019-07-25.snippet: When two ecologists hiking in New Zealand discovered this stump, they had to figure out how it could still be alive.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: In a rain forest near Auckland, New Zealand, a leafless kauri tree stump rises a few feet off the ground. These trees can become giants: The country’s biggest, Tāne Mahuta, or the “Lord of the Forest,” has grown 168 feet high, with a 115-foot canopy.
2019-07-25.headline_main: Tree Stumps Are Dead, Right? This One Was Alive

2019-07-25.snippet: Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez has been unable to forge a multiparty alliance in the fragmented Parliament, and the country faces the prospect of fresh elections.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: MADRID — The Spanish prime minister, Pedro Sánchez, lost a bid to form a government on Thursday after failing to make a multiparty alliance, raising the chances that the country will be forced to hold another national election to try to break the political deadlock.
2019-07-25.headline_main: Sánchez Loses Bid to Form a Government, Prolonging Deadlock in Spain

2019-07-25.headline_main: Quit Your Terrible Job

2019-07-25.abstract: The photographer’s once-taboo images have lost their power to shock, and feed into outworn stereotypes, a critic argues.
2019-07-25.snippet: The photographer’s once-taboo images have lost their power to shock, and feed into outworn stereotypes, a critic argues.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: Thirty years after Robert Mapplethorpe’s death, the legend still obscures the photographs. His demise at 42 from AIDS, during the height of the American epidemic, gave a tabloid stamp to the authenticity of his sexually transgressive art. And right at that time arose the political controversy that enshrined him as a martyr to artistic freedom: a Congressional uproar over a traveling exhibition and then a grandstanding criminal obscenity case in Cincinnati. His place in political history is secure.
2019-07-25.headline_main: Has Robert Mapplethorpe’s Moment Passed?

2019-07-25.abstract: A reader wonders whether it’s better to make his girlfriend happy or adhere to an age-old custom.
2019-07-25.snippet: A reader wonders whether it’s better to make his girlfriend happy or adhere to an age-old custom.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: My girlfriend and I have decided we’d like to get engaged. Before we do, I want to ask her parents’ permission — not because she belongs to them. I just think it’s polite and would start our relationship on the right note. I would also like to do this in person. But my girlfriend wants to get engaged this summer, which would prevent my asking them in person because they live across an ocean. I’ve asked her to wait a bit to let me do what I think is the right thing, but she is resistant. She said waiting will make her sad. What should I do?
2019-07-25.headline_main: Permission to Marry? Is It 1950?

2019-07-25.abstract: Jeff Goldblum plays a genial freelance lobotomist in Rick Alverson’s joyless, yet weirdly beautiful vision of 1950s America.
2019-07-25.snippet: Jeff Goldblum plays a genial freelance lobotomist in Rick Alverson’s joyless, yet weirdly beautiful vision of 1950s America.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: More times than I can count, I have thanked the movie gods for Jeff Goldblum, whose lanky, often loquacious presence can lighten almost any project. Even so, he has his work cut out in “The Mountain,” Rick Alverson’s ferociously controlled, adamantly depressive story of a 1950s road trip taken by Andy (Tye Sheridan), a recently bereaved young man, and Dr. Wallace Fiennes (Goldblum), the itinerant psychiatrist who befriends him.
2019-07-25.headline_main: ‘The Mountain’ Review: Dutiful Minds

2019-07-25.headline_main: Ukraine Seizes Russian Tanker That It Says Blockaded a Disputed Strait

2019-07-25.abstract: The federal government has not executed anyone since 2003, but the attorney general announced that five inmates will be put to death starting in December.

2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The federal government will resume executions of death row inmates after a nearly two-decade hiatus, Attorney General William P. Barr said Thursday, countering a broad national shift away from the death penalty as public support for capital punishment has dwindled.
2019-07-25.headline_main: U.S. to Resume Capital Punishment for Federal Inmates on Death Row

2019-07-25.abstract: When my husband died, I was soothed by the hand-designed furniture he left behind. Eventually, some of it had to go.
2019-07-25.snippet: When my husband died, I was soothed by the hand-designed furniture he left behind. Eventually, some of it had to go.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: In my family, the old saying “The shoemaker’s daughter goes barefoot” had special meaning. My mother and father manufactured high-fashion women’s shoes sold in Bloomingdale’s and Saks, while I opted to wear construction boots or clogs on most days.
2019-07-25.headline_main: Letting Go of the Sentimental but Not Very Comfortable Couch

2019-07-25.snippet: The nation’s Parliament approved amnesty for Nuril Maknun, whose case threw a rare spotlight on sexual harassment in Indonesia.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — An Indonesian bookkeeper who rose to national prominence after she was sentenced to jail for recording her boss to prove he was sexually harassing her is expected to receive amnesty from the country’s president soon.
2019-07-25.headline_main: Indonesian Woman Jailed for Recording Boss’s Harassment to Be Given Amnesty

2019-07-25.abstract: It denies a fair day in court to people who could face death when sent back to their countries.
2019-07-25.snippet: It denies a fair day in court to people who could face death when sent back to their countries.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: The Trump administration’s expansion of the use of fast-track deportations through “expedited removal” will create a “show me your papers” regime nationwide in which people — including citizens — may be forced to quickly prove they should not be deported. This policy allows Immigration and Customs Enforcement to quickly deport someone without going before an immigration judge, undermining American principles of fundamental fairness and putting United States citizens, permanent residents and asylum-seekers at risk of wrongful deportation.
2019-07-25.headline_main: The Human Cost of Fast-Track Deportation

2019-07-25.abstract: A downside of social living among monkeys and chimpanzees, a new study suggests, is being at greater risk of deadly disease.
2019-07-25.snippet: A downside of social living among monkeys and chimpanzees, a new study suggests, is being at greater risk of deadly disease.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: In the jungles of Ivory Coast, monkeys and chimps forage for food, sleep in trees and travel in groups. Not far behind follow primatologists, like Jan Gogarten, a postdoctoral researcher at the Robert Koch Institute in Germany.
2019-07-25.headline_main: A Brutal Disease Kills Monkeys. Flies Could Be Spreading It.

2019-07-25.abstract: There’s a lot more to the case against Mr. Trump and his associates.
2019-07-25.snippet: There’s a lot more to the case against Mr. Trump and his associates.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, in sworn congressional testimony, Special Counsel Robert Mueller publicly confirmed 100 percent of the devastating findings of his report, and made clear that his inquiry does not exonerate the president. Within 24 hours, though, the conversation has coalesced around a few superficial observations: Mr. Mueller underperformed and the Republicans overplayed their hand, but in the end, this is just about the end of the road for investigations around President Trump, let alone talk of impeachment.
2019-07-25.headline_main: What the Mueller Hearings Did Not Tell Us

2019-07-25.abstract: A sought-after drug policy expert, and often a maverick, he favored decriminalizing pot but remained wary of full-scale commercial legalization.
2019-07-25.snippet: A sought-after drug policy expert, and often a maverick, he favored decriminalizing pot but remained wary of full-scale commercial legalization.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: Mark A. R. Kleiman, a prominent drug policy apostate who favored what he viewed as a sensible middle ground on marijuana — eliminate criminal sanctions for selling and using it but preclude full-blown commercial legalization — died on Sunday in Manhattan. He was 68.
2019-07-25.headline_main: Mark Kleiman, Who Fought to Lift Ban on Marijuana, Dies at 68

2019-07-25.snippet: The two projectiles North Korea launched off its east coast on Thursday were a new type of ballistic missile, South Korea says.

Biden Jr. entered the 2020 presidential campaign with wide support from black voters and a reservoir of good will stemming from his eight years as an unswervingly loyal vice president to Barack Obama — a huge head start in a primary where African-Americans will play a decisive role.

The team set the major league record for most home runs in a single season with 264. It stood for 21 years, broken by the 2018 Yankees, who hit three more.

2019-07-25.abstract: At least 55 pro-government forces and 54 civilians were killed in Afghanistan during the past week.
2019-07-25.snippet: At least 55 pro-government forces and 54 civilians were killed in Afghanistan during the past week.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: At least 55 pro-government forces and 54 civilians were killed over the last week of fighting in Afghanistan. The deadliest of the attacks took place in Takhar Province, where the Taliban attacked and captured two security bases in Ishkamish District, killing 24 soldiers and 13 police officers. Six police officers were also wounded. Both bases were later recaptured by reinforcements, which arrived for backup belatedly. In Logar Province, nine civilians were killed in an American airstrike on the Khaki Dag area of the Baraki Barak District, where a community of Kuchi nomads lived. The United Nations confirmed the casualties.
2019-07-25.headline_main: Afghan War Casualty Report: July 19-25

2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: Some graphic novels are so visually stunning that you can readily imagine print dealers of the future slicing out pages for individual sale, as riveting out of context as extracts from a 19th-century field guide. Daria Tessler’s exquisite CULT OF THE IBIS (Fantagraphics Underground, $29.99) falls into this category, a tour de force in black and white. Nearly every picture balances a sense of wonder and menace — stopping you in your tracks even as the plot races ahead.

2019-07-25.abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
2019-07-25.snippet: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: The venerable Spanish novelist Javier Marías, answering our By the Book questions this week, disavows the concept of a “national literature.” Readers who agree with him may take heart from the example of David Szalay, whose novel “Turbulence” tops our latest list of recommended titles: Szalay was born in Montreal, raised in Beirut and London, and now lives in Budapest, and his novel (set largely in airports and on airplanes) is just as global and deracinated as that background might lead you to expect. On the other hand there’s Campbell McGrath, a poet who is every bit an American writer, and whose substantial volume of new and selected work, “Nouns & Verbs,” closes out this week’s recommendations. In between we have a novel set in a small English village; an intellectual biography of the French mathematician André Weil and his sister, the philosopher Simone Weil; a close look at Greenland and its journey to the center of climate science; and a history of Theodore Roosevelt’s rise that’s also about the rise of American dominance in the 20th century.
2019-07-25.headline_main: 6 New Books We Recommend This Week

2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: JAY ELECTRONICA at 99 Scott (July 28, 6 p.m.). One of hip-hop’s most elusive personalities, this rapper has spent more than a decade dodging fans’ eager pleas for a proper debut album. In 2007, he released his breakout project, “Act 1: Eternal Sunshine (The Pledge),” an experimental collage piece built on the soundtrack to “Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind.” Since then he has dropped just a handful of his own singles, and taken guest turns on tracks by Chance the Rapper, Mac Miller and others. Despite his resistance to the brisk pace of contemporary rap, Electronica’s much-lauded lyricism and ruminations on spirituality and struggle continue to captivate. mean.red

2019-07-25.abstract: There is a more glaring reason to impeach Trump: racism.
2019-07-25.snippet: There is a more glaring reason to impeach Trump: racism.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: One day, browsing Tinder, imagine that you come upon the profile of an obese, orange-haired real estate magnate and proud, raging racist. The first line of his bio: “Mexicans are rapists.” Formative business experience: Not renting to blacks. One of his profile pictures is a hand drawing of the continent of Africa across which he has scrawled the word “shithole.” Muslims: Don’t let them in. Jews, he tolerates, because sometimes you need a lawyer or an accountant, but he will also give a fair hearing to the very fine people who hate Jews. For this guy, anyone of color should be viewed always and entirely through the lens of that color, laboring permanently under a cloud of suspicion: Check their birth certificate. Hold them in cages. Send them back.
2019-07-25.headline_main: Stop Trying to Make Mueller Happen

2019-07-25.abstract: Temperatures are near or above 100 degrees in some places, and air-conditioning can be scarce. Here’s how to find relief in nine popular destinations.
2019-07-25.snippet: Temperatures are near or above 100 degrees in some places, and air-conditioning can be scarce. Here’s how to find relief in nine popular destinations.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: Across much of Europe, temperatures were setting records this week. In Paris, even before the thermometer hit 108.7 degrees on Thursday, beating a high mark set in 1947, the air felt like a furnace, and along sidewalks, people ducked into even the tiniest slivers of shade seeking relief. Prague hauled in water trucks to douse overheated locals and visitors in the city center, while Rome opened air-conditioned sports centers to people at risk. Thursday was the hottest July day ever recorded in the United Kingdom, with temperatures reaching 100.6 Fahrenheit in Cambridge, England. It’s only the second time in history that temperatures above 100 Fahrenheit have been recorded anywhere in the country. Things weren’t much cooler in London: Kew Gardens in west London registered 99.9 Fahrenheit on Thursday, and Heathrow reached 98.9.
2019-07-25.headline_main: How to Stay Cool During Europe’s Heat Wave

2019-07-25.abstract: Hundreds of thousands of Americans have coronary bypass surgery each year, and few die. Here’s what experts say happened to a national hero.
2019-07-25.snippet: Hundreds of thousands of Americans have coronary bypass surgery each year, and few die. Here’s what experts say happened to a national hero.
2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: Neil Armstrong, the first man to walk on the moon, died in 2012 at age 82 after what should have been routine heart surgery. When nurses removed wires linked to a temporary pacemaker, he bled profusely into the membrane surrounding the heart. He died a week later.
2019-07-25.headline_main: Neil Armstrong Died After Heart Surgery. That May Have Been Avoidable.

2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: The mourners came from every corner of the city, thousands filing beneath the soaring vault of Riverside Church to honor Hector Figueroa, among the country’s most dynamic and influential labor leaders. Mr. Figueroa, president of 32BJ S.E.I.U., a New York local of the Service Employees International Union, died of a heart attack on July 11 at 57. His memorial service on Wednesday was part funeral and part political rally, a rousing celebration of the working people and human values that Mr. Figueroa championed.

2019-07-25.lead_paragraph: If an artist were to choose colors for portraits of public officials to represent their records on climate change, one color would suffice for Donald Trump: charcoal black. How better to capture the president’s efforts to increase the extraction of coal, oil and gas at a time when emissions from these fuels are likely to expose tens of millions of people to life-threatening heat waves, coastal flooding, severe storms and water shortages.

2019-07-26.snippet: A streaming comic book adaptation gives fresh meaning to the word “antihero.” And rent “Dumbo” to catch up with recent Disney remakes.
2019-07-26.lead_paragraph: THE BOYS Stream on Amazon. A trailer for this streaming series adaptation of comic books by Garth Ennis and Darick Robertson features eye gouging, machine guns, lots of swearing and what appears to be a baby that fires lasers from its face. And that trailer is only about two minutes long. The thrust of the series — whose showrunner is the “Supernatural” creator Eric Kripke — is something like a dirty, topsy-turvy take on “The Avengers,” set in a world where badly behaving celebrity superheroes abuse their powers. Karl Urban plays Billy Butcher, the leader of a squad assembled to keep the superheroes’ misbehavior in check. That turns out to be a bit like employing hyenas to babysit coyotes.

2019-07-26.abstract: At the end of her sophomore year in college, Mary Beth Keane’s writing teacher gave her a summer reading list that changed her life.
2019-07-26.snippet: At the end of her sophomore year in college, Mary Beth Keane’s writing teacher gave her a summer reading list that changed her life.
2019-07-26.lead_paragraph: When I was a kid in the late 1980s, the reading material in my house consisted of: our local newspaper, an Irish newspaper and Reader’s Digest, which came only once a month. My favorite section in Reader’s Digest was called “Drama in Real Life” and featured a true story about a life-threatening experience. Once, a babysitter asked me where my younger sisters’ bedtime books were kept. I told her there weren’t any books, but she could try reading “Drama in Real Life” to them if she wanted. On that occasion, the story was about a man who was cutting down trees on his property and somehow touched his chain saw to a steel wire. The saw got stripped of its blades and tore him up like shrapnel. I don’t remember how he survived, but I do remember that my sisters were riveted. What power, I thought, to be able to bring people to the edge of their seats, impatient to know what would happen next.
2019-07-26.headline_main: She Grew Up in a House Without Books. A Teacher Helped Her Realize She Could Write One Herself.

2019-07-26.abstract: Lori Gottlieb analyzes the benefits — and side effects — of bibliotherapy.
2019-07-26.snippet: Lori Gottlieb analyzes the benefits — and side effects — of bibliotherapy.
2019-07-26.lead_paragraph: The first book I brought up to one of my therapy patients was Mary Karr’s “The Liars’ Club.” A young woman had been telling me about how ashamed she was of her parents, how she hid her family history from friends and romantic partners because, she reasoned, if she were to tell anyone the truth of her upbringing, nobody would understand.
2019-07-26.headline_main: Your Therapist’s Prescription? The Right Book.

2019-07-26.abstract: In a city known for samba, “nobody expects a black, poor woman to play the violin.”
2019-07-26.snippet: In a city known for samba, “nobody expects a black, poor woman to play the violin.”
2019-07-26.lead_paragraph: Morro da Providência is one of Rio de Janeiro’s oldest favelas. For Gláucia da Silva, a young classical musician, the 30-minute hike from the base of the favela to her mother’s house follows a steep incline and a walkway lined with silver-dollar-sized bullet holes.
2019-07-26.headline_main: Meet the ‘Orchestra of the Street’ Bringing Classical Music to Rio’s Favelas

2019-07-26.abstract: Most people hurt themselves when they try to outsmart the markets, the latest data shows. Humility is a better strategy.
2019-07-26.snippet: Most people hurt themselves when they try to outsmart the markets, the latest data shows. Humility is a better strategy.
2019-07-26.lead_paragraph: Forget about getting everything right. Most people are so consistently wrong that merely avoiding major errors is enough to set you apart from the pack.
2019-07-26.headline_main: Investors Are Usually Wrong. I’m One of Them.

2019-07-26.abstract: Tim Alberta speaks to us about “American Carnage,” his gripping new account of the Republican Party.
2019-07-26.snippet: Tim Alberta speaks to us about “American Carnage,” his gripping new account of the Republican Party.
2019-07-26.lead_paragraph: PARTY CRASHER In the chaotic world of American politics, about the only predictable event these days may be the regular release of a new book about the Trump administration — a phenomenon that describes nearly two dozen titles to date and that may soon include a memoir by the president’s eldest son as well as, eventually, one by the president himself. This week, the latest installment in the genre, “American Carnage: On the Front Lines of the Republican Civil War and the Rise of President Trump,” by Tim Alberta, enters the nonfiction list at No. 2. Most others of its ilk have also appeared there, proving, perhaps, that the one other reliable variable in national politics may be the reading public’s apparently insatiable appetite for Trumpiana.
2019-07-26.headline_main: How Did We Get From Compassionate Conservatism to the Party of Trump?

2019-07-26.abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
2019-07-26.snippet: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
2019-07-26.lead_paragraph: THE AGE OF RESPONSIBILITY: Luck, Choice, and the Welfare State, by Yascha Mounk. (Harvard, $14.95.) A political theorist traces the shift from “responsibility-as-duty” to “responsibility-as-accountability” — in other words, when responsibility was no longer about looking after those in need and instead about rewarding the good and punishing the bad. Mounk argues that holding individuals responsible for their circumstances is a flawed view.
2019-07-26.headline_main: New in Paperback: ‘The Family Tabor,’ ‘Into the Hands of the Soldiers’

2019-07-26.abstract: The most storied label in jazz turns 80 this year. Hear the music that shaped its legacy.
2019-07-26.snippet: The most storied label in jazz turns 80 this year. Hear the music that shaped its legacy.
2019-07-26.lead_paragraph: After hearing Meade (Lux) Lewis and Albert Ammons at the historic “From Spirituals to Swing” concert at Carnegie Hall in late 1938, Albert Lion approached the famed stride pianists, and a few weeks later, they entered a New York studio and made the first Blue Note recordings. Lion invited Ammons back in spring 1939, this time with a band, to record a few sides in the chugging boogie-woogie style that Ammons had recently helped popularize. Christened the Port of Harlem Jazzmen, the thrown-together sextet was the first full-on ensemble recorded for the label.
2019-07-26.headline_main: A History of Blue Note Records in 15 Albums

2019-07-26.abstract: Eliza Shapiro, an education reporter, and Dodai Stewart, deputy editor of the Metro desk, recently discussed the backlash against charter schools with New York Times subscribers.
2019-07-26.snippet: Eliza Shapiro, an education reporter, and Dodai Stewart, deputy editor of the Metro desk, recently discussed the backlash against charter schools with New York Times subscribers.
2019-07-26.lead_paragraph: Charter schools were once hailed by supporters as a way to save public education in big urban districts. Founders presented them as a way to offer low-income minority families safe, orderly schools with rigorous academics, and they were embraced across the country as a hopeful alternative.
2019-07-26.headline_main: How Did Charter Schools Lose Their Luster? Our Reporter Explains

2019-07-26.lead_paragraph: Since Deb Perelman started Smitten Kitchen in 2006, the cooking site has spawned legions of fans, two popular cookbooks and a drool-inducing Instagram account, where it’s easy to lose an hour (or five) in images of gooey chocolate-chip cookies, herb-sprinkled pastas and juicy chicken roasted just so.

2019-07-26.abstract: Whisky, wine and memories as friends mourned Michael Seidenberg — and also Brazenhead, a secret bookstore he ran out of his Manhattan apartment.
2019-07-26.snippet: Whisky, wine and memories as friends mourned Michael Seidenberg — and also Brazenhead, a secret bookstore he ran out of his Manhattan apartment.
2019-07-26.lead_paragraph: On the Upper East Side of Manhattan last Saturday, a somber procession of New Yorkers walked into an apartment building and rang a buzzer to attend the wake of a bookseller named Michael Seidenberg. Up some stairs and down a corridor, the din of a gathering poured from a door, and they entered a small apartment lined with long libraries and heaps of paperbacks that houses Mr. Seidenberg’s clandestine secondhand bookstore, Brazenhead. Wading into the crowd, they hugged old friends and wiped away tears.
2019-07-26.headline_main: A Wake for New York’s Last Pirate Bookseller

2019-07-26.abstract: Faced with severe factory overcapacity at home and tariffs on exports to the U.S., Beijing wants to finish a much-delayed Asian free-trade pact.
2019-07-26.snippet: Faced with severe factory overcapacity at home and tariffs on exports to the U.S., Beijing wants to finish a much-delayed Asian free-trade pact.
2019-07-26.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China has too many factories making too many goods. Thanks to its punishing trade war with the United States, its biggest overseas customer isn’t buying like before.
2019-07-26.headline_main: China Needs New Places to Sell Its Mountain of Stuff

2019-07-26.abstract: The genre is in a state of diffusion and streaming dominates listening habits. But Blue Note is still dedicated to influencing the music’s path forward.
2019-07-26.snippet: The genre is in a state of diffusion and streaming dominates listening habits. But Blue Note is still dedicated to influencing the music’s path forward.
2019-07-26.lead_paragraph: The name Blue Note Records calls to mind a once-regnant sound in jazz: the hard-bop of the 1950s and ’60s, with its springy four-beat swing rhythm, its spare-but-lush horn harmonies, its flinty, percussive piano playing. Imagine a smoky room with a horn player blowing fiercely over a strolling standup bass, and you’re hearing the Blue Note sound. Think of a modernist, cobalt-hued album cover, with blocky title text and a photo of a studious young musician hunkered over an instrument, and you’re envisioning the Blue Note look.
2019-07-26.headline_main: Blue Note Records at 80: Can a Symbol of Jazz’s Past Help Shape Its Future?

2019-07-26.abstract: The owner of the McNally Jackson bookstores prefers paper over screens. But she’ll still order Seamless for dinner.
2019-07-26.snippet: The owner of the McNally Jackson bookstores prefers paper over screens. But she’ll still order Seamless for dinner.
2019-07-26.lead_paragraph: In the 15 years since Sarah McNally opened her first McNally Jackson shop on Prince Street, she has become a key player in the city’s indie bookstore resurgence. Her third location, scheduled to open at South Street Seaport in August, will feature a wine bar that will also serve all manner of toast. “I wanted a simple food concept I couldn’t lose my shirt on,” she said. Ms. McNally, 44, who lives in Greenwich Village with her son, Jasper Jackson, 11, and their dog, Chief, notes that unlike many of her peers, she rarely gets away on summer weekends. “We should though, right? Sometimes I feel like life is rushing by so quickly and I still haven’t figured out how to live. I’m late and getting later all the time.”
2019-07-26.headline_main: How Sarah McNally, Seasoned Bookseller, Spends Her Sundays

2019-07-26.abstract: Ali Fitzgerald imagines Agatha Christie’s famous detective on a hunt for clues through the New York City subways.
2019-07-26.snippet: Ali Fitzgerald imagines Agatha Christie’s famous detective on a hunt for clues through the New York City subways.
2019-07-26.headline_main: What if Hercule Poirot Went Sleuthing on the L Train?

2019-07-26.abstract: “Noise, color, body contact” for all.
2019-07-26.snippet: “Noise, color, body contact” for all.
2019-07-26.lead_paragraph: It sounds like a human freight train: wheels clattering around the turns, bodies thumping against each other, toe stops shrieking against the track. A rainbow of hair and wheels goes by in a blur, shouts and grunts punctuating the din. It’s part endurance race, part wrestling match, combining strategy, athleticism and camp. And it’s all done on roller skates.
2019-07-26.headline_main: The Long and Surprising History of Roller Derby

2019-07-26.abstract: Karin Slaughter killed a character with antifreeze; Peter Swanson used cashews and a missing EpiPen. Welcome to the devious minds of thriller writers.
2019-07-26.snippet: Karin Slaughter killed a character with antifreeze; Peter Swanson used cashews and a missing EpiPen. Welcome to the devious minds of thriller writers.
2019-07-26.lead_paragraph: More women than men choose to kill people with poison, but one of my male characters in “Strawberry Yellow” uses ordinary rhubarb to murder his nemesis. It actually makes perfect sense as he’s a farmer and the mystery takes place in the salad bowl of agricultural California. The leaves of rhubarb contain a high level of oxalic acid, which can cause kidney failure. Boil the leaves and mix them together with chopped rhubarb and strawberries to make the most beautiful and deadly pie.
2019-07-26.headline_main: We Asked 13 Novelists, From Lee Child to Ruth Ware, ‘What’s the Best Murder You Ever Wrote?’

2019-07-26.snippet: On Western Europe’s highest mountain, the number of inexperienced climbers is growing and climate change is taking a toll. Are new safety measures enough?

2019-07-26.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The main issue at stake in last Sunday’s election of the upper house of Parliament was whether the ruling coalition and its allies would win the super majority they needed to amend Japan’s pacifist Constitution. They didn’t. Less noted was another failure of the prime minister’s camp: The small number of female candidates it presented.
2019-07-26.headline_main: Japan’s Leader Wants to Empower Women. Just Not in His Party.

2019-07-26.abstract: Piper Kerman, whose experiences and memoir inspired the Netflix prison dramedy, now works with inmates in correctional facilities.
2019-07-26.snippet: Piper Kerman, whose experiences and memoir inspired the Netflix prison dramedy, now works with inmates in correctional facilities.
2019-07-26.lead_paragraph: In 2004, Piper Kerman, who had pleaded guilty to money laundering violations, entered federal prison. Thirteen months later, she left it. She wrote a memoir, “Orange Is the New Black,” and that book, in the hands of the showrunner Jenji Kohan, became one of the first hits of the streaming era. Piper Kerman became Piper Chapman (Taylor Schilling), a WASP convict whose story hooks the viewer just long enough to introduce dozens of characters who don’t have her white, middle-class advantages.
2019-07-26.headline_main: Why the ‘Orange Is the New Black’ Author Returned to Prison

2019-07-26.abstract: They reflect the country’s widening inequality. Their trustees must help fix this.
2019-07-26.snippet: They reflect the country’s widening inequality. Their trustees must help fix this.
2019-07-26.lead_paragraph: America’s museums are more than repositories of ancient Greek statues and Renaissance paintings. They are guardians of a fading social and demographic order. On Thursday, Warren Kanders resigned from the board of the Whitney Museum of Art, after protests over his company’s sale of tear gas grenades that were reportedly used on asylum seekers. His case reveals the extent to which museums have become contested spaces in a rapidly-changing country.
2019-07-26.headline_main: Museums Need to Step Into the Future

He was Australia’s hedonist hero, a painter of grand and voluptuous canvases who hung out with Bob Dylan, Janis Joplin and Dire Straits.

2019-07-26.abstract: An exhibition in Paris juxtaposes tools, fossils and Cro-Magnon skulls with works of modern and contemporary art.
2019-07-26.snippet: An exhibition in Paris juxtaposes tools, fossils and Cro-Magnon skulls with works of modern and contemporary art.
2019-07-26.lead_paragraph: PARIS — It’s always wise to doubt those who praise an art exhibition as “groundbreaking”: a promise of false dawns, a cliché best left to the marketing teams. But at the Pompidou Center, the most important exhibition of the Parisian season really does feel like it’s unearthed something new. It rewrites the history of modern art by digging deeper than ever before, and scatters the art of the 20th century with shards of primordial basalt and bone.
2019-07-26.headline_main: Painted on the Cave Wall, an Image of Modern Life

2019-07-26.lead_paragraph: As a working mother of two, Dr. Leslie Bottrell has little time for exercising, let alone getting herself to a fitness studio in her Upper West Side neighborhood for a group class. And because her schedule varies week to week, she can’t settle into classes with fixed time slots anyway.

Maangchi, the YouTube cooking star whose real name is Emily Kim, was on vacation on the far eastern end of Long Island this summer, staying in a condominium just steps from the Montauk beach. One day I went out to visit her, and she taught me to make cheese buldak (above), fiery chicken beneath a blanket of mozzarella, a Korean answer to chicken Parm.

2019-07-26.abstract: The only thing that can save America is us.
2019-07-26.snippet: The only thing that can save America is us.
2019-07-26.lead_paragraph: Robert Mueller’s congressional testimony this week was revealing, but not for what it told us about the Trump campaign’s associations with Russia. In the hours and days after Mr. Mueller gave his opening statement before the House Judiciary Committee, it became clear how tenaciously many liberals and progressives are clinging to fantasy — not just that President Trump will eventually find himself impeached and removed, but also that they can advance their values by means of legal machination rather than political vision. And at a moment of intense polarization in American politics, this fantasy is especially shortsighted.
2019-07-26.headline_main: The Mueller Fantasy Comes Crashing Down

2019-07-26.abstract: It’s hard not to feel joyful around a spread of taco kit-style tacos.
2019-07-26.snippet: It’s hard not to feel joyful around a spread of taco kit-style tacos.
2019-07-26.lead_paragraph: On Saturday night, we had dinner at my brother’s place, pulling up to his house at the end of a blazing hot day to find he had made a full taco night spread, a mirage shimmering just past the front door. These were not tacos in the “It was like I was at the market in Mexico City!” sense. It was a taco kit-style deal, with seasoned sautéed ground beef and turkey; a platter of soft tortillas and hard shells; bowls of shredded lettuce, tomatoes, cheese, sliced avocado, salsa; black beans and rice on the side; cold beer. It was a blast, the most fun I’d seen kids and grown-ups have sharing the exact same meal together in a long time.
2019-07-26.headline_main: The Dinner Everyone Freaks Out Over

2019-07-26.abstract: Wine cocktails are as relaxed and thirst-quenching as they are easy to make.
2019-07-26.snippet: Wine cocktails are as relaxed and thirst-quenching as they are easy to make.
2019-07-26.lead_paragraph: The path of high-summer cocktail hour matches the ease and pace of its season: Open the refrigerator, take out a bottle, relish the cold condensation in your hand, pour, mix, drink.
2019-07-26.headline_main: Summer Drinking at Its Simplest

2019-07-26.abstract: Under attack from President Trump, the House Democratic quartet self-named “the squad” is being embraced by its party. But beneath the bonhomie, tensions remain.

Somebody snapped a picture, and one of them — Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez — posted it on Instagram with a one-word caption: “Squad.”
2019-07-26.headline_main: ‘The Squad’ Rankles, but Pelosi and Ocasio-Cortez Make Peace for Now

2019-07-26.snippet: Sam Goodwin, 30, had visited 183 countries before he was detained in Syria. After being held for two months, he was reunited with his family.

2019-07-26.snippet: Exposure to art — even uncomfortable art — is healthy, stimulating, and worthy of students’ debate.
2019-07-26.lead_paragraph: After half a century of intermittent debate and protest, the San Francisco Board of Education voted unanimously in June to whitewash the 13 murals depicting the life of George Washington that line the halls of a high school named for the first president. The murals’ offense is that they depict some ugly truths about the history of the United States, namely two of its original sins: slavery and the Native American genocide.

2019-07-26.lead_paragraph: BAYREUTH, Germany — The Wartburg castle, so central to Wagner’s “Tannhäuser” that it’s part of the opera’s full title, makes an appearance only briefly in Tobias Kratzer’s new production, which opened the Bayreuth Festival here on Thursday. At the beginning of the overture, a video projected onstage shows the medieval fortress in sweeping drone footage fit for a tourism commercial. Then it’s gone.

2019-07-26.abstract: A roundup of things our editors — and a few contributors — are excited about in a given week.
2019-07-26.snippet: A roundup of things our editors — and a few contributors — are excited about in a given week.
2019-07-26.lead_paragraph: Swimwear, according to the designer Maayan Sherris, has to perform simultaneous tasks that your day-to-day clothes do not: it must both support the body and also move with its contours, all while under water. It’s a challenge that the Parsons graduate eagerly tackled in 2015 during a research project with the Columbia University women’s swim team, for which she translated the athletes’ needs into a line of sensible bikinis and functional one-pieces. “I like that my clothing serves a purpose,” Sherris said about the swimsuit label Babes in Bathers, which she launched in 2016 using her findings from that project. Now, after two years of development, the brand is ready to introduce a more expansive men’s offering that, in keeping with Sherris’s objective, addresses the needs and preferences of real swimmers. “I wanted to make sure I had a comfortable swimsuit that fits really well to the male body,” she said.
2019-07-26.headline_main: T Suggests: Taiwanese Pastries, Art Deco-Inspired Block Prints and More

The design was an instant success, with the first batch reportedly selling out within two days. As one of many fledgling feminists trying to make sense of the cultural whiplash surrounding the F-word at that time, I loved the shirt, because it expressed a growing feeling of something nascent but urgent.

2019-07-27.abstract: Pippa Bianco’s debut feature about sexual assault and memory comes to HBO, and Viola Davis’s heist drama is available to stream.
2019-07-27.snippet: Pippa Bianco’s debut feature about sexual assault and memory comes to HBO, and Viola Davis’s heist drama is available to stream.
2019-07-27.lead_paragraph: SHARE 10 p.m. on HBO. This feature debut from the writer-director Pippa Bianco is an unflinching look at sexual assault in the digital age. The film opens with a 16-year-old, Mandy (Rhianne Barreto), waking up on her front lawn after a night of partying, not sure how she got there. In the morning, she receives a barrage of text massages from friends alerting her to a grainy video that’s been circulating. It shows Mandy lying on the floor unconscious, while her crush (Nicholas Galitzine) removes her clothes. But it’s what the video doesn’t show that propels the film, as Mandy works to uncover the truth, growing more isolated in the process. “Bianco uses a depressingly familiar story of high-school partying gone wrong to explore sometimes uncomfortable questions about gender, agency and collective guilt,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. The film joins “The Tale” and the gritty teen drama “Euphoria” in HBO’s catalog of female-led stories about sexual assault, anxiety and the unreliability of memory.
2019-07-27.headline_main: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Share’ and ‘Widows’

2019-07-27.lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN, P.R. — The uprising that toppled Puerto Rico’s leaders might be traced to a day earlier this month, when the governor, Ricardo A. Rosselló, was not even on the island. He was on vacation in Europe, curating his Instagram feed with smiling pictures of him and his wife savoring Paris.
2019-07-27.headline_main: 15 Days of Fury: How Puerto Rico’s Government Collapsed

2019-07-27.abstract: The Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions Movement aims to press Israel to change its policies toward the Palestinians. It has generated heated debate and much misinformation.
